Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WTP-2PY1-JD3N-53C5-00000-00Fixing the internet2019-08-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:51:22ZLexisNexisPg. 27Fixing the internetStory by Walter Frick

As the other half of the world comes on line, what are we giving them?

"How did the internet get so broken?" That question anchors season 3 of "Crazy/Genius", the tech podcast hosted by Derek Thompson of The Atlantic. Its preview trailer runs through a litany of problems linked to the internet, from surveillance to misinformation to algorithmic bias.

"What if we just tried turning it off for, like, a week," jokes Vox's Jane Coaston, "just to see what would happen?" The ill effects of the internet are also examined in a clutch of current books from Coders by journalist Clive Thompson (no relation to Derek) to Tools and Weapons by Microsoft president Brad Smith and Carol Ann Browne.

In Coders, Thompson profiles programmers at social media giants including Facebook, Instagram and Pinterest and examines their role in making the internet what it is today. Early America was run by lawyers, he observes, and 20th-century America by engineers. Now the coders are in charge. They have played a disproportionate role in creating the major internet platforms, transforming economies, cultures and governments in the process.

That's less than ideal, Thompson believes, because coders are disproportionately young, white men from privileged backgrounds who design products to solve problems in their own lives. "When you have a homogenous cohort of people making software and hardware, they tend to produce work that works great for them but can be useless, or even a disaster, for people in other walks of life," he says. In Beyond the Valley, media studies professor Ramesh Srinivasan extends that critique to include a geographic caveat: "Chinese, Western and white male interests dominate the content and systems that power the internet, rather than those who reflect the full diversity of us online," he writes.

We were promised "an internet that acts as a 'global village' ... that creates, or at least supports, equality" but that's an internet "we haven't yet received".

The pursuit of profits - that is, the internet's transition from a non-commercial Eden for researchers and hobbyists into a bonanza of capitalism - is another force driving things off the rails. The founders of Instagram didn't "actively set out to erode anyone's self-esteem", says Thompson. But the need to continually expand the user base to fuel ad sales - by encouraging people to showcase their best moments in the addictive pursuit of "likes" - overrode concerns about the feelings of inadequacy and the unhealthy fear of missing out that users were reporting.

"The money was deforming decisions - what code gets written and why." Srinivasan concurs, pointing out that many of the big tech companies "are branded as public, civic and virtuous but, in reality, are dominated by a single logic - extending profitability and economic value". Technologists' relentless focus on efficiency has also led us astray. Coders enjoy automating and optimising, but "even the programmers themselves can be surprised, and disenchanted, by how their zeal for optimisation can produce unexpected and freaky side effects", says Thompson. "Uber flooded the streets ... with cars, which was terrific for riders but less so for drivers, many of whom began to find it harder and harder to piece together a steady living, given the frenetic competition." Srinivasan contends that "efficiency on our consumer platforms can ... disturb our sense of security and privacy". Targeted ads are incredibly efficient, for example, but they can also be incredibly creepy.

The relentless drive toward optimisation relies on an entirely new category of workers who toil behind the scenes. In Ghost Work, anthropologist Mary Gray and computer scientist Siddharth Suri explore the lives of people who, using crowdsourcing marketplaces like Amazon Turk, carry out essential online microtasks, such as filtering harmful content for Google. The book reveals that although some internet work is rewarded and celebrated, much of it is poorly compensated and invisible, and takes a sometimes devastating human toll.

Even assuming that, overall, the internet does far more good than harm, it will remain broken unless our institutions, culture and policies change to make the most of it. And that challenge is becoming only more urgent as more people come online. As technologist Jim Cashel writes in The Great Connecting, it took 25 years from the launch of the web browser Mosaic, in 1993, for half the world to come online. But the other half will gain access in the next three to five years. He asks: "What are the major players involved in connecting the planet doing to prepare [for] expanded connectivity?" Cashel's advice boils down to: anticipate, facilitate, mitigate, regulate and celebrate. To date, there's been too much of the last and too little of all the rest - especially regulation. Cashel calls for an international "digital tribunal" to help countries co-ordinate regulatory efforts.

For Gray and Suri, a first step in fixing the internet is empathy. We need to recognise what happens behind the scenes of the sites and services we use every day and better understand the consequences of our actions. They recommend that more ghost work platforms take a "double bottom line" approach to their business, balancing profits with concern for their workforce.

Srinivasan would like to put more control in the hands of users and argues for spreading a more robust version of digital literacy that includes "the capacity to reflect, analyse, and create" so that more of us can contribute to technological development.

In Tools and Weapons, Microsoft's Smith puts his hope in the rule of law. "The tech sector cannot address these challenges by itself," he writes. "The world needs a mixture of self-regulation and government action." That means more than just the public sector holding the private one to account; it also works the other way around. To illustrate, Smith points to Microsoft's decision to sue the US government after the National Security Agency issued warrants requiring it to turn over customer data.

To improve the internet, we must fight the tendency to ignore its tremendous potential. A few years ago, a Reddit user wondered what would be the hardest thing to explain to someone arriving from 50 years in the past. One user answered: "I possess a device, in my pocket, that is capable of accessing the entirety of information known to man. I use it to look at pictures of cats and get in arguments with strangers." I love that quote because it so perfectly captures our inability to put the internet to good use.

Surely we can do better.

Walter Frick is an editor at HBRFor more exclusive HBR content go to: theaustralian.com.au/ business/ harvardbusiness-review

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5SJ4-FS61-DY9P-N1MH-00000-00Fix the regulatory flaws in our fragile financial system, or risk another crisis2018-06-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:51:22ZLexisNexisNEWS; TEASERSPg. 16Fix the regulatory flaws in our fragile financial system, or risk another crisisAnat Admati

OVER the past 800 years governments have consistently had a role in financial crises - either causing them (for example, by defaulting on their debts), or by failing to control excessive borrowing and risk-taking in the private sector.

The US Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission found that the main causes of the 2008 crisis were avoidable failures of corporate governance and policy. Yet the system remains fragile, inefficient, and dangerous. Despite reforms put in place after crises, bankers, politicians, and regulators consistently overstate the system's health and the effectiveness of new rules.

Doing more to prevent crises requires the political will to address the underlying flaws in the system. But governments' relationships with their country's financial sector can often be too close to enable substantial reform. Financial institutions themselves, meanwhile, have little incentive to change.

As it stands, poorly-designed regulation continues to allow the largest institutions to borrow on privileged terms and remain opaque, while fears of another "Lehman moment" mean that, in the event of a crisis, policymakers are likely to ensure that ordinary depositors are paid in full to prevent system collapse.

This situation normalises recklessness. As we have seen in the past, by the time problems are visible, they can easily escalate. Individuals lack the right expertise and are unable to bring about meaningful change even if they know or sense that something is wrong.

The dysfunction of governance and policy is among the reasons that ordinary people are currently turning away from capitalism as a system. This situation fuels polarisation that can enable populist demagogues to manipulate public anger away from these issues.

Economic analyses do not always help if, as is often the case, they are obscure or seem to justify the system.

Focusing on how to respond to sudden "shocks" obscures the possibility of reducing the likelihood of crises without sacrificing the system's benefits.

The financial sector illustrates prevalent corporate governance problems elsewhere. Carillion, for example, used accounting tricks and other tactics to hide its weakness, digging itself into a hole that caused more collateral harm when it finally collapsed.

Meanwhile tech companies' abuse or carelessness with personal data has caused identity theft and helped spread propaganda and fake news.

If the global financial crisis wasn't enough to drive effective reforms, what will work to ensure that corporations serve society without causing unnecessary harm? Will the backlash against Facebook, for example, force long-term change to Big Tech, or better data security? The next financial crisis may well start from a massive cyber attack.

Fortunately, we need not abandon capitalism to make it work better. The obstacles to change, while challenging, are man-made. We must question dubious assumptions and demand that policymakers create and enforce proper rules.

The increasing influence of activist investors and customers over large corporations, along with grassroots campaigns enabled by social media, offer some hope. Change will require public awareness and collective empowerment to take control away from narrow interests and hold those in power accountable.

£ Anat Admati is professor of finance and economics at the Stanford Graduate School of Business.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5PTH-S641-DY0W-44Y2-00000-00Flake is Out; Tax Reform Push; Anthem EPS Beats Estimates; Alaska Revenue Misses Estimates; Paul Ryan: President Trump, Bob Corker Feud2017-10-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:51:23ZLexisNexisFlake is Out; Tax Reform Push; Anthem EPS Beats Estimates; Alaska Revenue Misses Estimates; Paul Ryan: President Trump, Bob Corker FeudLanhamFULL TEXT

UNIDENTIFIED MALE (voice-over): Live from Riyadh, Saudi Arabia at the Future Investment Initiative, here's Maria Bartiromo with a special edition of "Mornings With Maria."

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX ANCHOR: Good Wednesday morning everybody, thanks for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, happy Wednesday to you. It is Wednesday, October 25th. Your top stories right now, 6:00a.m. on the East Coast.

Jeff Flake is out, the Arizona senator says that he will not run for reelection when his term expires next year just like his Tennessee colleague, Bob Corker. Flake blamed "outrageous and undignified behavior" by President Trump as the reason behind this decision. The White House was quick to respond.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SARAH HUCKABEE SANDERS, PRINCIPAL DEPUTY WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: The president is focused on doing this. He went to the Hill and met with republican senators to talk about tax reform, to push his legislative agendas.

The voters of these individual senator states are speaking in pretty loud volumes. I think that they were not likely to be reelected and I think that shows that the support is more behind this president than it is those two individuals.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The decisions come as the GOP pushes for tax reform. The commander-in-chief himself made an appearance on Capitol Hill yesterday to rally the party to get this done.

Speaker of the House Paul Ryan also weighed in insisting that the tensions would not hurt the effort.

Meanwhile, a little bit of earnings blitz on Wall Street, among the top names reporting earnings today, Boeing and Coca Cola. We will bring you the analysis and the numbers as soon as they hit the tape. Tell you how they may impact markets.

The meantime markets are flat right now, Futures indicating a flat opening at the start of trading, DOW Industrial down about four points, Nasdaq down about 10 points as you see there.

In Europe, stocks are mixed, similar story there. Take a look as we get earnings streaming now, we're going to run it on the tape there. Indications here, FTSE100 is down 15 points, the CAC Krones in Paris is up 12, and the DAX Index right around breakeven.

In Asia Overnight, markets closed mostly higher as you see here with the exception of the Nikkei Average in Japan pulling back by half of one percent.

Bank rolling controversy, the salacious dossier that target President Trump during the election now we find out reportedly funded in part by the Clinton campaign and the Democratic National Committee. More on the shocking news claims just ahead this morning.

Total devastation, new satellite images from NASA revealing the extent of the immense damage left behind by the California wildfires, we've got that for you.

And batter up, we've got all the highlights as the World Series gets underway in Los Angeles. All that coming up.

Plus, I am coming to you live this morning from Saudi Arabia once again. I'm live, day two of the Future Investment Initiative here in Riyadh this morning. A lot happening. People are praising his royal highness, the crowned prince, of course yesterday.

You saw my panel when I spoke with the crown prince about what he's trying to do opening up the country to foreign investment, as well allowing women to drive, that doesn't sound radical to us but it's certainly is a radical idea here in Saudi Arabia.

In fact, this crowned prince is not afraid to attack the issues that are important to the world. He is trying to reduce extremism in Saudi Arabia to less than five percent in the next two to three years.

Apparently it is some 20 percent which is what we're hearing. He's got the investment fund called the PIF, he's seeking return of between six and nine percent annually. He's looking at six pools of investment and hoping to get the overall value of the fund up $2 trillion by 2030.

In fact, they're saying behind closed doors it's a joke that it's $2 trillion, we're actually looking to even exceed $2 trillion. We know that the Saudis gave Softbank and their vision fund $45 billion, that's $45 billion of the $100 billion of that Softbank fund which is investing in technology so aggressively.

That's one of the sources of revenue for the PIF here, that fund. Also they have invested with the Blackstone Group, a big infrastructure fund, so they're looking to invest in infrastructure around the world.

They're also hoping to privatize things here in Saudi Arabia. They want to privatize the rail system, the airports, lot of infrastructure that they're expecting to also bring big returns. They're talking about oil prices that they just cannot rely on the price of oil, where it is right now.

So they're looking to diversify. Real fundamental change happening in Saudi Arabia, I can't tell you what I've learned enough here that there is serious change happening here in Saudi Arabia and that is why you have so many big hitters from across the world here trying to get a piece of this action.

It's another big day of exclusive news making interviews this morning. Among the big names I'll be speaking with coming up, Treasury Secretary Steven MNuchin is with me today. The CEO of Blackstone Group, Steve Schwarzman.

EY Global Chairman and CEO, Mark Weinberger. The CEO of the London Stock Exchange, Xavier Rolet is here. And Revolution Chairman and CEO, Steve Case.

And joining from New York this morning is Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell. CFRA Investment Strategist, Lindsey Bell. And Business and Economics Professor of the King's College, Brian Brenberg. Good morning everybody, great to see you.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Great to see you Maria.

BRIAN BRENBERG, KING'S COLLEGE PROFESSOR OF BUSINESS AND ECONOMICS: Good morning.

LINDSEY BELL, CFRA INVESTMENT STRATEGIST: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Lots to talk about Dagen. What's on your agenda?

MCDOWELL: That Hillary Clinton and her team and the DNC were behind that controversial discredited dossier put together. I hope they own it and I hope the hammer comes down on everybody associated with the dossier put together against President Trump.

BARTIROMO: It's incredible Dagen. How long have we been saying on this program collusion between the Trump Administration and the Russians does not exist. And here we are looking at this other collusion with the democrats. It's just outrageous.

MCDOWELL: Your compass on this story from its first breath, everything to do with Russia and Hillary Clinton, her campaign and the DNC, you have been spot on from moment one and I can't reiterate that enough.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. We've got a lot to talk about this morning.

Our top story right now, a Republican Party feud on Capitol Hill, two senators taking aim at President Trump. The president renewing his attacks against Bob Corker after the Tennessee senator said that the White House should leave it to Congress to decide how to pay for the tax cuts. Corker fired back questioning his own support for the president.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: The beginning of the administration you supported the president, do you regret that now?

BOB CORKER (R-TN): Well, what do you think? Like if --

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: I think that's a yes.

CORKER: I think people -- like I think there were many people, I was one of those that hope that he would rise to the occasion as president and he aspire to lead our nation instead of dividing it. And it's obvious his political model and governing model is to divide.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Meanwhile, Arizona Senator Jeff Flake announcing that he will not seek reelection next year. Flake have been facing a tough race after repeatedly criticizing President Trump.

Announcing his decision on the Senate floor, Flake echoed Corker once again slamming the president.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. JEFF FLAKE, (R) ARIZONA: Reckless, outrageous and undignified behavior has become excused and countenanced as tone it like it is when it is actually just reckless, outrageous, and undignified.

And when such behavior emanates from the top of our government it is something else, it is dangerous to a democracy.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Elsewhere on Capitol Hill, House Speaker Paul Ryan insisted that these tensions going on would not hurt efforts to pass tax reform. Something the president echoed when I sat down with him late last week.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. PAUL RYAN, (R-WI) SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE: I don't think it changes our efforts on tax reform. I know Bob who supported the budget wants to get tax reform, I know the president wants to get tax reform.

BARTIROMO: Even your supporter say, "He's got fantastic policies, we want to see this through" but the bickering and the feuding actually gets in the way. So obviously the feuding with Senator Corker, I think there's a personal thing going on between you and Senator McCain.

Do you worry that this bickering and feuding gets in the way of your agenda?

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: No, and sometimes it helps to be honest with you. So we'll see what happens at the end. But I think actually sometimes it helps. Sometimes it gets people to do what they're supposed to be doing.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: And joining me right now is special interview, Colony NorthStar Executive Chairman, Thomas Barrack, Jr. is with me. And Tom, it's great to have you on the program this morning.

THOMAS BARRACK, JR., EXECUTIVE CHAIRMAN, COLONY NORTHSTAR: Thanks Maria, great to be here.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us. Now I know that you are long time friends, you've been an adviser to President Trump. Do you think tax reform can get passed even though we've got all of these fights happening?

BARRACK, JR.: Absolutely. I think it's a necessity for everybody. What we've witnessed is not a misfire by President Trump, it's boys playing badly in the sandbox.

And for midterm elections, everybody just has to get on with business and do the right thing and I think tax reform is the key to corporate restructuring and organization, capital expenditure investment, and a couple hundred dollars more in the average American's pocket is going to be meaningful. So they have to get it done.

BARTIROMO: So you think this will move the needle on economic growth? You think that it will do what the president is hoping it will do in terms to create jobs?

BARRACK, JR.: Growth and production are the only two components that can move the needle. So growth is very difficult in an environment like this, so increased production is the answer and increase investment to get that production as a necessity.

BARTIROMO: So when the senators arrive for their weekly policy lunch yesterday with the president, some of the senators apparently were ready for show. Watch this, got to get your reaction.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Do you envision any problems at this luncheon when the president will be there with Senator Corker?

SEN THOM TILLIS, (R) NORTH CAROLINA: No, I don't think so. I'm going to bring some popcorn. It will be interesting to watch.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Senator Thom Tillis tweeted out this photo as well. According to reports there were not any fireworks at the meeting. So how would you recommend, how do you advice the president here that the proceed with these senators especially Flake and Corker while he's trying to get things done and needs their votes?

BARRACK, JR.: Well I think he's proceeding with his intention, he has two of the best individuals capable of monitoring this and Secretary MNuchin who you're going to talk to this afternoon and Gary Cohn.

So the machinery is working and these politicians know that it's a necessity for them on behalf of their constituencies to get something done and to stop bickering and nobody toys with president. He's very well equipped to handle himself and these battles and I think it will get done and it will get done well.

BARTIROMO: So you don't think this pushback on the state and local tax deduction is going to get in the way of passage? That could really move markets, Maria. So, this is a big question. Now, others say, look, even if Taylor ends up in this role, once you get into the seat, you moderate your views just a little bit because now you're actually in a decision-making role. So, there's a big question there. And I think that's going to create some uncertainty in the markets.

BARTIROMO: What do you think, Dagen?

MCDOWELL: I think that the markets, given the kind of jubilant market that you've seen are not factoring in the potential unknown of a new Fed chief. And again, you get into this guessing game as Brian was pointing out: who would do what? Again, Kevin Warsh's name was out there, earlier this week. J. Powell, J. Powell is going to be more like Janet Yellen. Is it going to be Janet Yellen? But if you get a new name in there, particularly John Taylor, you'll go to have potentially months of uncertainty. I think that that maybe not cause a market crash, but it could cause a lot of volatility that you are not seeing today.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Well, and what Brian said, you know, here's a guy who has voiced, you know, his feeling that rates have to be much higher, John Taylor has said it. But, you know, when I asked the president who'd he wanted to see running the Fed, he said, well, I'm looking at Taylor and I'm looking at Powell. So, he basically said, you know, I mean, he didn't mention Gary Cohn, he didn't mention Kevin Warsh. But you're right, those are two very different people in terms of their approach to interest rates. And we don't know, Lindsey, if the whole experiment is going to work whereas as they're winding down the balance sheet $4.5 trillion, and how disrupted that could be to markets. Meanwhile, so far, earnings have been the story in terms of driving market action.

BELL: Right. And I think when it comes to the Fed chair, it's going to be: what does Trump want higher rates or lower rates? It's going to be something to watch. Earnings, so far, though, are supporting the market right now. One thing I will say is we've seen 2018 estimates, 12 percent growth. It hasn't moved too much, and while that doesn't include any reform in there, it'll be interesting -- the reform is priced into the market.

BARTIROMO: So, it's 12 percent profit growth, Lindsey, for 2018?

BELL: Correct.

BARTIROMO: OK. We'll be right back, much more from the Future Investment Initiative here in Riyadh.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

END

urn:contentItem:5PTH-S5V1-JBHT-D361-00000-00Flake is Out; Tax Reform Push; Anthem EPS Beats Estimates; Alaska Revenue Misses Estimates; Paul Ryan: President Trump, Bob Corker Feud2017-10-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:51:22ZLexisNexisFlake is Out; Tax Reform Push; Anthem EPS Beats Estimates; Alaska Revenue Misses Estimates; Paul Ryan: President Trump, Bob Corker FeudLanhamFULL TEXT

UNIDENTIFIED MALE (voice-over): Live from Riyadh, Saudi Arabia at the Future Investment Initiative, here's Maria Bartiromo with a special edition of "Mornings With Maria."

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX ANCHOR: Good Wednesday morning everybody, thanks for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, happy Wednesday to you. It is Wednesday, October 25th. Your top stories right now, 6:00a.m. on the East Coast.

Jeff Flake is out, the Arizona senator says that he will not run for reelection when his term expires next year just like his Tennessee colleague, Bob Corker. Flake blamed "outrageous and undignified behavior" by President Trump as the reason behind this decision. The White House was quick to respond.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SARAH HUCKABEE SANDERS, PRINCIPAL DEPUTY WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: The president is focused on doing this. He went to the Hill and met with republican senators to talk about tax reform, to push his legislative agendas.

The voters of these individual senator states are speaking in pretty loud volumes. I think that they were not likely to be reelected and I think that shows that the support is more behind this president than it is those two individuals.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The decisions come as the GOP pushes for tax reform. The commander-in-chief himself made an appearance on Capitol Hill yesterday to rally the party to get this done.

Speaker of the House Paul Ryan also weighed in insisting that the tensions would not hurt the effort.

Meanwhile, a little bit of earnings blitz on Wall Street, among the top names reporting earnings today, Boeing and Coca Cola. We will bring you the analysis and the numbers as soon as they hit the tape. Tell you how they may impact markets.

The meantime markets are flat right now, Futures indicating a flat opening at the start of trading, DOW Industrial down about four points, Nasdaq down about 10 points as you see there.

In Europe, stocks are mixed, similar story there. Take a look as we get earnings streaming now, we're going to run it on the tape there. Indications here, FTSE100 is down 15 points, the CAC Krones in Paris is up 12, and the DAX Index right around breakeven.

In Asia Overnight, markets closed mostly higher as you see here with the exception of the Nikkei Average in Japan pulling back by half of one percent.

Bank rolling controversy, the salacious dossier that target President Trump during the election now we find out reportedly funded in part by the Clinton campaign and the Democratic National Committee. More on the shocking news claims just ahead this morning.

Total devastation, new satellite images from NASA revealing the extent of the immense damage left behind by the California wildfires, we've got that for you.

And batter up, we've got all the highlights as the World Series gets underway in Los Angeles. All that coming up.

Plus, I am coming to you live this morning from Saudi Arabia once again. I'm live, day two of the Future Investment Initiative here in Riyadh this morning. A lot happening. People are praising his royal highness, the crowned prince, of course yesterday.

You saw my panel when I spoke with the crown prince about what he's trying to do opening up the country to foreign investment, as well allowing women to drive, that doesn't sound radical to us but it's certainly is a radical idea here in Saudi Arabia.

In fact, this crowned prince is not afraid to attack the issues that are important to the world. He is trying to reduce extremism in Saudi Arabia to less than five percent in the next two to three years.

Apparently it is some 20 percent which is what we're hearing. He's got the investment fund called the PIF, he's seeking return of between six and nine percent annually. He's looking at six pools of investment and hoping to get the overall value of the fund up $2 trillion by 2030.

In fact, they're saying behind closed doors it's a joke that it's $2 trillion, we're actually looking to even exceed $2 trillion. We know that the Saudis gave Softbank and their vision fund $45 billion, that's $45 billion of the $100 billion of that Softbank fund which is investing in technology so aggressively.

That's one of the sources of revenue for the PIF here, that fund. Also they have invested with the Blackstone Group, a big infrastructure fund, so they're looking to invest in infrastructure around the world.

They're also hoping to privatize things here in Saudi Arabia. They want to privatize the rail system, the airports, lot of infrastructure that they're expecting to also bring big returns. They're talking about oil prices that they just cannot rely on the price of oil, where it is right now.

So they're looking to diversify. Real fundamental change happening in Saudi Arabia, I can't tell you what I've learned enough here that there is serious change happening here in Saudi Arabia and that is why you have so many big hitters from across the world here trying to get a piece of this action.

It's another big day of exclusive news making interviews this morning. Among the big names I'll be speaking with coming up, Treasury Secretary Steven MNuchin is with me today. The CEO of Blackstone Group, Steve Schwarzman.

EY Global Chairman and CEO, Mark Weinberger. The CEO of the London Stock Exchange, Xavier Rolet is here. And Revolution Chairman and CEO, Steve Case.

And joining from New York this morning is Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell. CFRA Investment Strategist, Lindsey Bell. And Business and Economics Professor of the King's College, Brian Brenberg. Good morning everybody, great to see you.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Great to see you Maria.

BRIAN BRENBERG, KING'S COLLEGE PROFESSOR OF BUSINESS AND ECONOMICS: Good morning.

LINDSEY BELL, CFRA INVESTMENT STRATEGIST: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Lots to talk about Dagen. What's on your agenda?

MCDOWELL: That Hillary Clinton and her team and the DNC were behind that controversial discredited dossier put together. I hope they own it and I hope the hammer comes down on everybody associated with the dossier put together against President Trump.

BARTIROMO: It's incredible Dagen. How long have we been saying on this program collusion between the Trump Administration and the Russians does not exist. And here we are looking at this other collusion with the democrats. It's just outrageous.

MCDOWELL: Your compass on this story from its first breath, everything to do with Russia and Hillary Clinton, her campaign and the DNC, you have been spot on from moment one and I can't reiterate that enough.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. We've got a lot to talk about this morning.

Our top story right now, a Republican Party feud on Capitol Hill, two senators taking aim at President Trump. The president renewing his attacks against Bob Corker after the Tennessee senator said that the White House should leave it to Congress to decide how to pay for the tax cuts. Corker fired back questioning his own support for the president.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: The beginning of the administration you supported the president, do you regret that now?

BOB CORKER (R-TN): Well, what do you think? Like if --

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: I think that's a yes.

CORKER: I think people -- like I think there were many people, I was one of those that hope that he would rise to the occasion as president and he aspire to lead our nation instead of dividing it. And it's obvious his political model and governing model is to divide.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Meanwhile, Arizona Senator Jeff Flake announcing that he will not seek reelection next year. Flake have been facing a tough race after repeatedly criticizing President Trump.

Announcing his decision on the Senate floor, Flake echoed Corker once again slamming the president.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. JEFF FLAKE, (R) ARIZONA: Reckless, outrageous and undignified behavior has become excused and countenanced as tone it like it is when it is actually just reckless, outrageous, and undignified.

And when such behavior emanates from the top of our government it is something else, it is dangerous to a democracy.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Elsewhere on Capitol Hill, House Speaker Paul Ryan insisted that these tensions going on would not hurt efforts to pass tax reform. Something the president echoed when I sat down with him late last week.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. PAUL RYAN, (R-WI) SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE: I don't think it changes our efforts on tax reform. I know Bob who supported the budget wants to get tax reform, I know the president wants to get tax reform.

BARTIROMO: Even your supporter say, "He's got fantastic policies, we want to see this through" but the bickering and the feuding actually gets in the way. So obviously the feuding with Senator Corker, I think there's a personal thing going on between you and Senator McCain.

Do you worry that this bickering and feuding gets in the way of your agenda?

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: No, and sometimes it helps to be honest with you. So we'll see what happens at the end. But I think actually sometimes it helps. Sometimes it gets people to do what they're supposed to be doing.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: And joining me right now is special interview, Colony NorthStar Executive Chairman, Thomas Barrack, Jr. is with me. And Tom, it's great to have you on the program this morning.

THOMAS BARRACK, JR., EXECUTIVE CHAIRMAN, COLONY NORTHSTAR: Thanks Maria, great to be here.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us. Now I know that you are long time friends, you've been an adviser to President Trump. Do you think tax reform can get passed even though we've got all of these fights happening?

BARRACK, JR.: Absolutely. I think it's a necessity for everybody. What we've witnessed is not a misfire by President Trump, it's boys playing badly in the sandbox.

And for midterm elections, everybody just has to get on with business and do the right thing and I think tax reform is the key to corporate restructuring and organization, capital expenditure investment, and a couple hundred dollars more in the average American's pocket is going to be meaningful. So they have to get it done.

BARTIROMO: So you think this will move the needle on economic growth? You think that it will do what the president is hoping it will do in terms to create jobs?

BARRACK, JR.: Growth and production are the only two components that can move the needle. So growth is very difficult in an environment like this, so increased production is the answer and increase investment to get that production as a necessity.

BARTIROMO: So when the senators arrive for their weekly policy lunch yesterday with the president, some of the senators apparently were ready for show. Watch this, got to get your reaction.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Do you envision any problems at this luncheon when the president will be there with Senator Corker?

SEN THOM TILLIS, (R) NORTH CAROLINA: No, I don't think so. I'm going to bring some popcorn. It will be interesting to watch.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Senator Thom Tillis tweeted out this photo as well. According to reports there were not any fireworks at the meeting. So how would you recommend, how do you advice the president here that the proceed with these senators especially Flake and Corker while he's trying to get things done and needs their votes?

BARRACK, JR.: Well I think he's proceeding with his intention, he has two of the best individuals capable of monitoring this and Secretary MNuchin who you're going to talk to this afternoon and Gary Cohn.

So the machinery is working and these politicians know that it's a necessity for them on behalf of their constituencies to get something done and to stop bickering and nobody toys with president. He's very well equipped to handle himself and these battles and I think it will get done and it will get done well.

BARTIROMO: So you don't think this pushback on the state and local tax deduction is going to get in the way of passage? Lot of people like a Peter King, like other New Jersey and New York senators -- congressman rather are saying, "Look, we can't vote for this because my constituents are going to get the tax increase."

BARRACK, JR.: Well you're going to have concessions everywhere. And when you think about it, that's actually an easy thing to give away if you had to. So at the end of the day, the consensus of what gets done will be a blend of those things but it will happen in the last day.

BARTIROMO: Tom, let me ask you about the news of the day, even the "Washington Post" is reporting this this morning which, of course, they are hard press to report anything against the Clinton campaign.

But Hillary Clinton campaign and the Democratic National Committee helped fund research that resulted in that now infamous dossier with allegations about President Trump's connections to Russia according to sources familiar with the matter. What did you make of that?

BARRACK, JR.: What I make of it is that the same issues that have alienated America to drive them to elect President Trump. Everybody's just fed up with it all. It's not one side or the other, we're ready for something else. President Trump has been that. I think that's all it is to say about it.

BARTIROMO: That's -- you're right. You know what, people wanted to shake up.

BARRACK, JR.: Totally.

BARTIROMO: And that's why President Trump was voted into office because they're sick and tired of just not understanding where the fairness is.

BARRACK, JR.: Because there is no fairness.

BARTIROMO: Right. Yes. All right. Let me turn to Colony, obviously one of the biggest names in Hollywood, Harvey Weinstein, we've been talking about the terrible situation for the women.

More than half a dozen women now accused Weinstein of sexual assault, more than 50 women have publicly detailed a range of inappropriate behavior by the movie mogul, over decades by the way.

It has been reported that your private equity arm of the company, Colony Capital maybe par -- or may want to buy (INAUDIBLE) all of the Weinstein Company, where does that stand right now Tom?

BARRACK, JR.: Well we've looked at -- if you remember, we owned Miramax and Miramax was a Weinstein creation that Disney had on for almost a decade. And we bought Miramax and Disney and it was a great investment for us.

The Weinstein Company has some of the same elements, it has a video library, it has a TV production group, and it has a lot of great people who work within it. The Weinstein name is finished, Harvey's actions regardless of what are unacceptable, inappropriate, and despicable.

And the company needed a capital gauge of clog to stop the bleeding while you could evaluate what's left of the pieces to salvage and that's what we've been doing. It's still a question as to whether we'll be successful or not but it's not a resuscitation of the Weinsteins, it's trying to salvage the pieces of the company so the creative talent and the production group can go forward.

BARTIROMO: Because they are good assets, they are very good assets, right?

BARRACK, JR.: Great assets. I mean, regardless of what else, one of the great independent filmmaking companies ever in history was at the hands of the Weinsteins, that's the good news and that's the bad news.

So in an area where content is everything and the digital era is making content even more valuable, that library harvested correctly can be of great value. It's separating the liabilities and the toxicity of what happened from the good people and the good product that's within the company and that's sometimes an art form, not a science.

BARTIROMO: The negotiation right now, is it overpriced?

BARRACK, JR.: No, it's over what it is.

BARTIROMO: What it is, yes. Because you just said a minute ago Weinstein name is done, I mean how can you go on with after what has happened, it's incredible.

BARRACK, JR.: You can.

BARTIROMO: Tom, good to have you on the program.

BARRACK, JR.: Thanks.

BARTIROMO: Tom Barrack. We'll take a break. We're live from Saudi, next. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. A suicide live streamed on Facebook, Cheryl Casone with these details now, Cheryl --

CASONE: Well Maria, good morning. Shocked viewers could not believe what they were watching. A distraught father in Turkey upset that his daughter got engaged without his permission committed suicide on Facebook Live.

The violent scene unfolded as he was speaking directly into the camera before he pulled a handgun with his left hand fired a single shot into his temple. Facebook has removed that video from the site.

Well President Trump allowing refugee admissions to resume under a stricter screening rules. This comes after the administration's 120-day ban on refugee admissions expired yesterday. Now, the president has also ordered refugees from 11 countries that post higher risk to U.S. national security to face even tougher scrutiny. The administration hasn't identified though yet those 11 countries.

Well Congress voting to overturn a banking rule from the Obama Administration that would have allowed consumers to bring class action law suits against their bank or credit card company. Vice President Pence cast the final vote to break the 50-50 tie.

The banking industry was pushing hard to rollback this regulation that came from the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau years ago. The Trump Administration and republicans say the rule harms the free market. The president now expected to sign that measure into law.

Well, earnings season in full swing, Anthem is out with better than expected third quarter adjusted earnings of $2.65 a share, of course, this company revenue of $22 billion slighted ahead of expectations.

And then Alaska Airlines out with a profit of $2.24 a share, $0.02 below the estimate. The stock is down about 11 percent so far year-to-date. There is the one year chart as well on Alaska.

And then let's take a look at Chipotle, they came out with pretty disappointing quarterly numbers. Same store sales falling short of what analyst were looking for. The stock is lower in the premarket Maria, down more than 10 percent from hurricanes, the consumer taste changing, to the higher price of avocadoes.

A lot of issues factored into these negative numbers coming out of Chipotle. And those are your headlines.

BARTIROMO: Wow, 10 percent big move there Cheryl on the downside. Okay, thank you so much. We should point out that these are just reported earnings and revenue better than expected.

We'll see if the stock moves on this but we've got revenue at $4.8 billion, better than the estimate earnings as well. Visa in the news right now. Stock is up about two percent right now higher on Visa.

We'll take a break. When we come back, mixed signals on healthcare after the president ended subsidies to the insurance companies and you said that they got rich off of ObamaCare. How is the industry reacting? I'll have an exclusive interview right here in Riyadh with the CEO of Prudential Financial, John Strangfeld coming up, that's next.

And then Amazon now giving businesses to prime treatment, two day shipping for some deliveries, what it will cost you, that story coming up.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. I'm Maria Bartiromo coming to you live this morning from the future investment initiative in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia.

Over in Washington, the republican controlled Congress is still looking to deliver win for President Trump on healthcare but Senate Majority Leader, Mitch McConnell is putting the responsibility back on the White House.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. MITCH MCCONNELL (R-KY), SENATE MAJORITY LEADER: What I'm waiting is to hear from President Trump what kind of healthcare bill he might sign. If there is a need for some kind of interim step here to stabilize the market we need a bill, the president will actually sign.

And I'm not certain yet what the president is looking for here but I'll be happy to bring a bill to the floor if I know President Trump would sign it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining me right now and a FOX Business Exclusive is the CEO of Prudential Financial, John Strangfeld. John, it's good to see you, thanks so much for joining us.

JOHN STRANGFELD, CEO, PRUDENTIAL FINANCIAL: Thank you. Good to see you too.

BARTIROMO: What do you think about all this uncertainty over what the president actually wants to replace ObamaCare with, impacting the industry overall, uncertainty over the tax package.

Are these pieces of legislation going to impact markets if we actually don't see closure soon?

STRANGFELD: I don't see the healthcare having a big impact on that. I think the uncertainty around tax and what the outcome of the taxes I think actually has a bigger impact. And it can be linked to other public policy objectives as well.

BARTIROMO: Because you really have to see a movement in economic growth and you think that happens from tax reform.

STRANGFELD: I think that can happen from tax reform and I also think there's certain public policy objectives that are important to be reflected in the tax reform as well.

BARTIROMO: Let's talk about Prudential Financial for a moment, you've changed the company obviously not a healthcare company, you've got a huge asset management -- wealth management division, $1.2 trillion assets under management.

How are you investing today? How are your clients viewing this market sentiment which obviously has been record setting?

STRANGFELD: Well, it takes different forms in different places. And so for example, in our particular case, we're a large insurance company, we're a large retirement company, and we're a large asset management.

$1.2 trillion, about two-thirds of that are institutional investors, such as those here in the Saudi Kingdom which is partly why I'm here. Everyone has a different objective in terms of what they're trying to accomplish. But many of them are apprehensive about what's going on in the marketplace and how the returns they can achieve match up with the obligations that they have in front of them.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I want to ask about retirement because we just came off of a couple of weeks of uncertainty with regard to what this administration might do with 401K plans and finally the president comes out and says there will be no change to your 401K. What was your take on that?

STRANGFELD: Well, that was a good conclusion.

BARTIROMO: Yes, it was.

STRANGFELD: So if you think about this, aging population not only in U.S. but in many countries shrinking government safety nets, corporate employers plans are less generous than they once were and people are living longer.

So when you combine all this together, it's a big challenge for people to maintain their quality of life in retirement. And the more we can do to have public policy that aligns with people's objectives of achieving that is really, really critical.

BARTIROMO: But you don't want any change in policy in terms of 401K?

STRANGFELD: Absolutely not.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I mean, what -- we're already looking at a situation where people don't have enough money in retirement.

STRANGFELD: They absolutely don't.

BARTIROMO: You don't want to change a 401K where an employee is able to get a match from the company.

STRANGFELD: Absolutely. In fact, we have -- we need more incentives to encourage people along the way. Not only that, many people have had their retirement risks shifted to their shoulders whether it's the savings or whether it's the risk of knowing how long they're going to live.

None of us know whether we're going to live to 72 or 102, so it's very difficult to know how we can save for that. Our parents generation had a pension check show up in the mailbox once a month.

BARTIROMO: Right, exactly.

STRANGFELD: We don't have that today. So people have to address that individually which is a much harder way to manage risk.

BARTIROMO: Now you're here as you just mentioned, you've got clients obviously -- a lot of your institutional clients including the Kingdom, I thought it was really interesting what the crowned prince has been saying in terms of the private investment fund.

They've got six pools of capital, they're -- they gave $45 billion to Softbank in that vision fund, they're investing in the Blackstone infrastructure fund. Where else do you think there's opportunity for an international investor like the Saudi Kingdom?

Are they looking U.S., Europe, where's the attractions?

STRANGFELD: Well what they have historically done is exported a lot of capital. Meaning, investments into other regions of the world, it takes many different forms (INAUDIBLE) examples that you mentioned.

But it's interesting from what the crowned prince was talking about yesterday is there's also going to be an added initiative, we're investing more extensively in their domestic marketplace as well.

BARTIROMO: Right. And Saudi is changing.

STRANGFELD: Yes. Saudi is changing and what's also fascinating about his efforts that were reflected in your moderated panel yesterday was the desire to link public policy with those objectives in ways (INAUDIBLE) other countries should consider replicating as well.

You have a much better prospect of achieving your objectives if public policy is an enabler to outcomes and clearly, he's focusing on having an enabling public policy.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I think it's incredible that he wants to get that Private Investment Fund, the PIF up to above $2 trillion in assets by 2030.

STRANGFELD: Yes. Yes, that's a big number.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

STRANGFELD: And I think it's -- I think it's actually quite achievable given what they've done and given what they (INAUDIBLE)

And by the way, they're very long-term investors which as are we which is what made -- we've been here for over 20 years which has made that relationship as strong as it is, they're thinking very long-term.

But the neat thing about his, the crowned prince was his thinking around the use of public policy to enable things that happened. Frankly, we could take a page out of the book in our country. We spend so much time on regulating versus enabling is a real opportunity there.

BARTIROMO: It's one of the reason that the Trump Administration has rolled back regulation so much really.

STRANGFELD: Exactly right.

BARTIROMO: John, it's good to see you.

STRANGFELD: Nice to see you too.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us.

STRANGFELD: Pleasure.

BARTIROMO: Nice to see you here in Saudi.

STRANGFELD: Pleasure.

BARTIROMO: John Strangfeld joining us there. Thank you John.

Coming up next, incredible new images of the devastating California wildfires and they're from space. NASA releasing the revealing pictures and we've got them for you. And then the L.A. Dodgers taking one of the World Series, but the real winner may be the team's right fielder, whose hair, well, took on Dodger blue and took it to a whole new level. We'll tell you about it. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

ANNOUNCER: Here again is Maria Bartiromo with a special edition of Mornings with Maria, live from Riyadh, Saudi Arabia at the future investment initiative.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back, I'm Maria Bartiromo. It is Wednesday, October 25th, happy Wednesday to you, everybody, thanks for joining me, your top stories right now, 6:30 a.m. on the East Coast. Mark Cuban means business. The billionaire sits down with Fox News to talk about a possible White House run in 2020. How Cuban claims he would help the middle class if he decides to take on President Trump, coming up. Meanwhile, earnings expected to drive markets once again.

We are in the thick of earnings season for the third quarter, three Dow components out before the opening bell this morning. Coca-Cola and Boeing are both due in the next two hours. We will bring you the numbers as soon as they hit the tapes. Visa reported a moment ago, delivering solid fiscal fourth-quarter results for visa. The credit card company beat expectations on both earnings and on revenue. We are breaking down those numbers, coming up. The stock is already up two percent as expected to tackle on 15 points on the Dow at the open, with a two percent rally in Visa.

Futures meanwhile, indicating a flat opening so far for the broader averages as you can see. European stocks are also mixed to a really flat on the session. Take a look at the European indices right here, and we see the FT 100 down about 10 points and the CAC Quarante up 15, the DAX Index in Germany up about 8. Fractional moves there. In Asia overnight, markets closed mostly higher. Take a look, as you see there, best performer, Hang Seng in Hong Kong, up half a percent.

California chard, NASA releasing stunning new satellite pictures revealing the true scope of the damage left behind by the massive wildfires still raging in the state. Twitter getting transparent, how the company is fighting back this morning amid revelations that Russia used social media to meddle in the U.S. election plus, the Dodgers scorch the Astros last night, the hottest World Series game, game one on record, watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

COMMENTATOR: Left field and it's deep and a wall and a turn. It's a two- run home run. Marwin Gonzalez runs out of room, Turner runs around the bases and the Dodgers take a 3-1 lead.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Wow, we have the highlights from the sizzling summer-like start to the fall classic, coming up this morning. But first, I am live, at day two at the Future Investment Initiative here in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia this morning. It's another big day of exclusive interviews, news-making interviews. We've got huge titans from across the world coming here because Saudi Arabia is in the midst of fundamental change.

I will be speaking, coming up, with Treasury Secretary Stephen Mnuchin, the CEO of the Blackstone Group Stephen Schwarzman, EY Global Chairman and CEO Mark Weinberger and London Stock Exchange CEO Xavier Rolet, coming up. But first, tax reform in the road to 2020, billionaire Mark Cuban seems to be setting up a primary challenge to President Trump during an interview with Fox News host Tucker Carlson last night. Cuban slammed Trump's tax plan and weighed in on how he would help the stagnant middle class.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARK CUBAN, OWNER OF NBA'S DALLAS MAVERICKS: The first thing I would do rather than a tax reform we're looking at right now, a decrease payroll taxes significantly, so that that money, instead of being -- instead of having every hour tax as it is now, that money would go right into the hands of the people who need it the most. I would focus on creating technology solutions. I think there's a way that we can reduce the size of government, the size of bureaucracy that deals with healthcare, but it's going to take somebody who understands technology that can introduce technology to find those solutions.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining us right now and the first on Fox Business interview is Revolution CEO and Chairman, and Former CEO of AOL, Steve Case, Steve, great to see you.

STEVE CASE, CEO AND CHAIRMAN OF REVOLUTION: Great to be back.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us, so your thoughts on this, Mark Cuban, going to run for president?

CASE: What (INAUDIBLE) I think we have three more years to go, but I love the fact that Mark's going to -- trying to throw some ideas out there to help the middle class.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I mean, so far, there's been such divisiveness in this country. What do you think about what the policies coming out of this administration have been so far?

CASE: Well, I think they are trying to focus onto things like tax reform (INAUDIBLE) get some traction. I've talked to the President and some of his advisors, Gary Cohn and Wilbur Ross and others about making sure that as they look at tax reform, they -- and try to focus on simplification. They also create the right investment in (INAUDIBLE) so entrepreneurs particularly (INAUDIBLE) have access to Capitol, so they can start companies and create jobs there.

We have this growing divide in the country where a lot of innovation and wealth creation and job creations happening in the coast. There are a lot of people in the country that do feel left out and left behind, so hopefully, that would be one of the areas as tax reform moves forward. It will be a more inclusive innovation economy. Last year, 75 percent of (INAUDIBLE) went to just three states.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

CASE: And so, we need to make sure everybody, everywhere really has a shot at the American dream.

BARTIROMO: Where do you see growth? I mean, you're really one of the first people to get on this, sort of, longevity bandwagon, wellness longevity with your Revolution Company. Tell me where do you see growth in the world today?

CASE: Well, I think the big opportunity is what I've called the third wave of the earn, the first wave is just getting everybody connected that we started AOL over three decades ago, only three percent of people are online, so getting (INAUDIBLE) was the first wave. The last 15 or 20 years is really the second wave building apps and services on top of the internet, Facebook and Google and so forth.

But the third wave is just now happening, it's really integrating the internet in seamless ways throughout healthcare and energy, food, agriculture, transportation, smart cities, a lot of things are up for grabs in the third wave, but I think it's going to require a different mind-set for entrepreneurs, partnerships, companies are going to be more important, policy, regulatory issues are going to become more important. And I also believe they will tie with (INAUDIBLE) the expertise and a lot of sectors like healthcare and farming is in the middle of the country.

So we're backing entrepreneurs who are close to those, you know, those industries, that's where the third break really will break out. It won't just be -- and I think we're kind of peak silicon valley here (INAUDIBLE) inside and people talking about peak oil. I think we're kind of peak silicon valley and talking about it will continue to be strong and vibrant. We're going to see a more inclusive innovation economy and entrepreneurs will regionalize within the United States and globalized really all around the world.

BARTIROMO: Yes, you make a good point, because when you -- when you were first, obviously, with AOL, it was a different moment in time in terms of the internet. We were -- we were on the doorstep of a new revolution, if you will, but today, it's about adding on to that. It's about really different stool -- different legs to the stool.

CASE: And integrating it. Something like Smart Cities. I was in Columbus a couple of weeks ago to get another Rise of the Rest tour to Ohio and Indiana and Michigan states like that. Columbus won the Smart City's challenge. They've got $50 million from the government to match that with $500 million and they're trying to create a model of Smart City which is exciting.

But, it's not just about the technology, it's not just about the software, how do you partner with other companies, G.E. and IBM, some of the biggest companies in the world, are partnering with the start-ups to create Smart Cities and how do you deal with some of the policies? Is there some tough privacy big brother issues, risk around cyberterrorism bringing down some of these Smart Cities, so that third wave innovation is not going to just going to be about coding and writing software and apps.

It's going to be really dealing with some of the most fundamental aspects of our lives, how we stay healthy, how we move around cities and doing - that in partnership with other companies and understanding growing importance of policy and therefore, you have to interact and engage with government which entrepreneurs generally are resistant of doing.

BARTIROMO: Is this part of the discussion on your panel today? You're here, you're going to be doing a panel, the world in 2030, creating value with the next generation which Richard Branson and David Bonderman.

CASE: Yes. That's really talking about what's happening in the next 10 or 20 years. I will talk a lot about a third wave and why it's going to require a different, kind of, approached entrepreneurship. We'll talk about it the Rise of the Rest, and how we're trying to encourage more entrepreneurship in more parts of the country, more parts of the world. We're also talking about impact investing.

We are hearing that theme at this conference and having business not just focused on profit, but also focus on purpose to having a broader impact that's resonating a lot of people -- young people who want to work for companies that stand for more than short-term profit, do business with companies as well as invest in those companies. So, the third wave innovation will be a big thing, the rise of the rest and more regional entrepreneurship and impact investment.

BARTIROMO: I think it's really interesting that so many large technology companies have investment arms and they're acquiring some of these start- ups, you know, those companies that don't want to go public because they don't want to deal with the regulatory environment, you've got the arm of Google, an arm -- an investment arm in Amazon, buying up some of these companies.

CASE: Which is actually great, a good way for them to drive forward and innovate some of the most interesting businesses now, that something like Google has android or things like that came through acquisition. And a great example that I saw two weeks ago in Indianapolis, sales acquired a company they called exact target for nearly $3 billion. They've now doubled the size were exact target for nearly$3 billion.

They've now doubled the size of that company, it's now 2,000 employees in downtown Indianapolis and the founder Scott Dorsey has gone on to start a venture fund and invest in the next generation of companies in Indianapolis. Look, everybody thinks the sales worth is a Silicon Valley company, and it is, their second largest outside of California is now Indianapolis. And that's what a perfect example of this idea to have Rise the Rest.

There's more cities that are rising, the brain drain where people leaving those cities are slowing, there's a boomerang of talent. We just need to follow with the venture capital. I think we can do to get more capital in hands and more entrepreneurs doing more interesting things in this third wave, will result in a much more inclusive innovation economy. We'll have a country where everybody feels optimistic about the future, not fearful.

BARTIROMO: This is really fascinating. You're absolutely right. Steve, I will be watching that panel. Thank you so much.

CASE: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Great to see you today, Steve Case joining us there. Coming up, Twitters big reveal, the social media company says that it will become more clear when it comes to who is posting political ads on the platform, in the wake of the surge or fake news during the last election. Plus, more big earnings out this morning, including Walgreens, does the healthcare debate affecting the company? We will bring It to you, next, back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. I'm Maria Bartiromo, coming to you live this morning from Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. We are watching major changes here in Saudi; we're also watching markets, of course, that is expected to open fractionally lower this morning. We'll see what happens after the earnings come out because that will likely dictate the numbers.

General Dynamics is one to watch today. The company is set to report third-quarter earnings before the opening bell this morning. Analysts are expecting earnings of $2.44 a share. The stock is up more than 40 percent over the last year. A pretty-good looking chart on General Dynamics.

Meanwhile, another name, SiriusXM, the broadcasting company also set to report its third-quarter earnings this morning. The analysis there -- analysts expecting earnings of four cents a share. Shares of SiriusXM are up nearly 30 percent this year.

NASA, meanwhile, releasing satellite photo which revealed the destruction caused by massive wildfires across Northern California. It's just incredible photos. Cheryl Casone with all the details right now in New York, Cheryl.

CASONE: Yes, Maria and these pictures are incredible. This NASA image we're going to show, you could see that the vegetation is in red, burned areas appear dark gray. More than 8,000 homes have burned in dozens of wildfires in Northern California. Firefighters are still trying to fully contain these fires; 42 people have been killed.

Well, Twitter says it will make its ads more transparent in an attempt to stay ahead of potential regulation. The company says people and groups that advertise on Twitter are going to be listed on Web site which will include details like how long the ads have been running. Remember Russian- backed accounts planted ads on Twitter and Facebook in an effort to influence the 2016 presidential election. Shares of Twitter up about six percent so far, this year.

Well, Amazon Prime is now available for businesses. The service started for companies who want free two-day shipping for certain things. So far, it's only available to businesses that are based here in the United States or Germany. Companies are going to be charged annual fees based on the size of the company. Shares of Amazon, though, under pressure a little bit, down a quarter percent in the premarket.

Well, the heat was on, literally, in Los Angeles last night. The temperature hit 103 for day one of the World Series, making it the hottest ever. No sweat though for the Dodgers, Chris Taylor smacking home run off the first pitch and the bottom of the first, giving Dodgers the early 1-0 lead. There it is. Clayton Kershaw, masterful, by the way, for the Dodgers; he erased all the postseason demons. And then, the big blow coming from Justin Turner.

ANNOUNCER: Turner lost a fly ball to left, it's hit pretty well. And it's gone! The two-run shot, Justin Turner! Dodger stadium erupts as they take a 3-1 lead here in the sixth.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: All right. Turner already has four homers this post-season. Dodgers went on to beat Astros 3-1. And then, check this out: Yasiel Puig showing his true colors on his head. Before the game, he prepared himself for the series by dying his hair, his Mohawk, anyway, a special color. Here's what it looks like. We'll show the big reveal -- yes, it's pure Dodger blue, Maria. So, big night in L.A. Another game tonight, by the way, we should add. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right, Cheryl, thank you. I don't know, I've heard of highlights, Dagen McDowell. But blue? I don't know that's a new one.

MCDOWELL: And by the way, on the T.V., it looks Vikings purple.

(LAUGHTER)

BRIAN BRENBERG, CHAIR, BUSINESS AND FINANCE PROGRAM AT THE KING'S COLLEGE: I like that.

(LAUGHER)

MCDOWELL: I think you have to actually bleach your hair white first, like, white, white, white. Then -- and then, put the color on it to make it look like that. Although, I -- yes.

BARTIROMO: To get just the right color.

MCDOWELL: Yes, exactly. Not that I know anything about hair dye.

BARTIROMO: We're talking about earnings. I know you've Lindsey sitting there. I don't know what you're looking at, Lindsey, as far as more important this earnings period, but what's it looking like so far? When we spoke last week, you said that the overall earnings expectation was profit growth of four percent, not so hot, are they exceeding the number?

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA RESEARCH: Yes, well, earnings growth now is looking at three percent. I used the S&P capital consensus estimate, so that's come down. G.E. had a lot to do with that. There is weak number on Friday. There's a huge weight in the index, so I'm looking forward to hearing more from these industrial and aerospace companies today. We'll get some big tech giants tomorrow. And that's going to be huge because those stocks have run off into the report. It could be a challenging quarter for them to see the stocks continue after that report. But the important thing is that --

BARTIROMO: Dagen, we've got dossier -- yes? Go ahead, Lindsey.

BELL: -- the topline sales are beating 71 percent of companies, that's huge. Usually, 55 percent beat, so that's a good sign for corporate America.

BARTIROMO: Dagen, we've got to talk about the other major story. We'll take a short break. When we come back, that's on the document -- maybe we should start calling it the Clinton dossier, stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back! I'm Maria Bartiromo, coming to you live from Riyadh, Saudi Arabia today. We want to look at investment happening here and across the world. We kick it off right now in Washington. Yesterday, President Trump reportedly had Republican leadership cast an informal vote between Jerome Powell and John Taylor for the said chair vacancy, coming in a few months. Reportedly, Taylor came as the winner. Brian Brenberg, let's talk about this. Because when I sat down with the president at the end of last week, he really did narrow it down to Taylor and Powell. But our sources say that when he asked the leadership: who would like to see John Taylor as head of the Fed, it was almost unanimous. They all raised their hand. What do you know?

BRENBERG: Well, John Taylor is very well-known in those circles. But I think this is an interesting question because if the president goes with Taylor, the question is: will Taylor do what everyone thinks Taylor will do, which is raise rates much more quickly than the Janet Yellen Fed has done. That could really move markets, Maria. So, this is a big question. Now, others say, look, even if Taylor ends up in this role, once you get into the seat, you moderate your views just a little bit because now you're actually in a decision-making role. So, there's a big question there. And I think that's going to create some uncertainty in the markets.

BARTIROMO: What do you think, Dagen?

MCDOWELL: I think that the markets, given the kind of jubilant market that you've seen are not factoring in the potential unknown of a new Fed chief. And again, you get into this guessing game as Brian was pointing out: who would do what? Again, Kevin Warsh's name was out there, earlier this week. J. Powell, J. Powell is going to be more like Janet Yellen. Is it going to be Janet Yellen? But if you get a new name in there, particularly John Taylor, you'll go to have potentially months of uncertainty. I think that that maybe not cause a market crash, but it could cause a lot of volatility that you are not seeing today.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Well, and what Brian said, you know, here's a guy who has voiced, you know, his feeling that rates have to be much higher, John Taylor has said it. But, you know, when I asked the president who'd he wanted to see running the Fed, he said, well, I'm looking at Taylor and I'm looking at Powell. So, he basically said, you know, I mean, he didn't mention Gary Cohn, he didn't mention Kevin Warsh. But you're right, those are two very different people in terms of their approach to interest rates. And we don't know, Lindsey, if the whole experiment is going to work whereas as they're winding down the balance sheet $4.5 trillion, and how disrupted that could be to markets. Meanwhile, so far, earnings have been the story in terms of driving market action.

BELL: Right. And I think when it comes to the Fed chair, it's going to be: what does Trump want higher rates or lower rates? It's going to be something to watch. Earnings, so far, though, are supporting the market right now. One thing I will say is we've seen 2018 estimates, 12 percent growth. It hasn't moved too much, and while that doesn't include any reform in there, it'll be interesting -- the reform is priced into the market.

BARTIROMO: So, it's 12 percent profit growth, Lindsey, for 2018?

BELL: Correct.

BARTIROMO: OK. We'll be right back, much more from the Future Investment Initiative here in Riyadh.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)
