Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WKK-XM41-DXH2-609H-00000-00Focus on Earnings; Interview with U.S. Secretary of Commerce Wilbur Ross; Held in Contempt; China Trade Turmoil; E.U. Investigating Amazon; Apollo 11 Anniversary; Big Tech under Fire; Donald Trump Administration Asylum Rules Facing Legal Backlash; El Chapo Faces Life in Prison at Sentencing Today; Neuralink Updates on Progress in Developing Brain-Machine Interfaces; Busch Hides Pop-Up Bar in National Forest; Eyeing Earnings and Economy Data2019-07-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:51:22ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTJason Trennert, Bob Nardelli, Capri Cafaro, Lindsey Bell, Wilbur Ross, Michael InserraNEWSFinancial071702cb.231Focus on Earnings; Interview with U.S. Secretary of Commerce Wilbur Ross; Held in Contempt; China Trade Turmoil; E.U. Investigating Amazon; Apollo 11 Anniversary; Big Tech under Fire; Donald Trump Administration Asylum Rules Facing Legal Backlash; El Chapo Faces Life in Prison at Sentencing Today; Neuralink Updates on Progress in Developing Brain-Machine Interfaces; Busch Hides Pop-Up Bar in National Forest; Eyeing Earnings and Economy DataMaria Bartiromo, Cheryl Casone

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Wednesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us.

I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Wednesday, July 17th.

Your top stories right now at 7:00 a.m. on button on the East Coast.

We are focused on earnings this morning. Lots of big names reporting their second quarter with banks in the spotlight this morning.

Bank of America this morning out with a beat on adjusted revenue and a beat on earnings per share. Nonetheless, the stock is down two-thirds of a percent. Profits rising on loan growth.

Bank of New York Mellon beat also on the bottom line and it is also raising its quarterly dividend by 11 percent.

And then there's PNC also with a beat on earnings but missed slightly on revenue.

The banks are coming in pretty much as expected as we saw last week as well.

Futures this morning indicating a gain at the start of trading meanwhile . Dow futures are up 14 points. S&P futures up 2. And the Nasdaq up 11 points right now.

Yesterday, the record run took a bit of a pause on Wall Street. Take a look. Markets were lower fractionally across the board. DowIndustrials were down 23 points, the S&P was down 10 and the Nasdaq lower by 35 at 4:00 on Wall Street yesterday.

European indices this morning are mixed. Take a look. FT 100 is down 10 points. The CAC 40 is down a fraction. But the Dax index in Germany is up three quarters of 1 point.

In Asia overnight -- trade fears drove markets lower there as well. As you can see it's fractional but nonetheless it's negative.

China trade turmoil continues. President Donald Trump saying that there is still a long way to go for a deal between the U.S. And China. We've got the fallout this morning.

And then crisis at the border, President Trump's new asylum restrictions also facing legal challenges. The ongoing battle coming up.

Big tech is under fire. Facebook's proposed cryptocurrency came under attack on the Hill yesterday. Investors are showing concern pushing bitcoin lower.

All those stories coming up this Wednesday morning. And joining me to break it all down: CFRA investment strategist Lindsey Bell is here. Former Home Depot CEO, former Chrysler CEO Bob Nardelli. Along with former Ohio state senate minority leader and American University School of Public Affairs executive in residence, Capri Cafaro.

Great to see you this morning.

CAPRI CAFARO, EXECUTIVE IN RESIDENCE, AMERICAN UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF PUBLIC AFAIRS: Absolutely.

BARTIROMO: It's been a good hour so far. We had a lot of breaking news there.

And interesting to see the different expectations for the economy. Nancy Lazar (ph), Anton Schutz (ph) seem a little more constructive on what we're seeing versus some of the conversation out there, indicating a 90 percent expectation for the Fed to cut rates in two weeks.

BOB NARDELLI, FORMER HOME DEPOT CEO: Yes. Yes. If we're not careful we're going to talk ourselves into dampening, you know, the enthusiasm and the growth that we've had in the economy. And you know, our discussion about Capex shifting from tradition brick and mortar to more technology, you know, more AI.

BARTIROMO: Yes. That doesn't get talked about enough.

NARDELLI: No, it should. And it should.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGISTT, CFRA: Technology cap ex is by far the largest component of the Capex component in GDP, of course . But I think there is reason for some concern out there because there's a lot of uncertainties, whether it be the China trade deal, whether it be geopolitical in nature, Brexit. There are some things that you do have to consider.

But the fact is, there seems to be good, solid strength here in the U.S., and the consumer remains very strong.

CAFARO: Right. Well, consumer confidence obviously seems very, very strong. But an area that does continue to concern me, certainly and just from being where I'm from, is the manufacturing sector. And that's where tariffs and trade issues really are going to play a part in that supply chain. I certainly don't need to tell you that.

NARDELLI: Yes.

BELL: And on that point we get the Beige Book today from the Fed in the afternoon.

CAFARO: Right.

BELL: And there will be a lot of anecdotal evidence about how tariff and trade are an --

(CROSSTALKING)

CAFARO: -- are having an impact on that --

BARTIROMO: Yes. We're really watching these purchasing managers' indexes which will be out interestingly the same day as the Fed meeting at the end of July. So we'll see what the manufacturing indices tell us.

But you're right, that's where the weak spots have been -- Ohio and manufacturing. We're talking about all that this morning.

And our top story this hour is "Held in Contempt". The House of Representatives preparing for a vote today on whether to hold Attorney General William Barr and Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross in criminal contempt for not complying with congressional subpoenas related to their efforts to add a citizenship question to the 2020 census.

Joining me right now is Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross. Mr. Secretary -- it's always a pleasure to see you. Thanks so much for joining me.

WILBUR ROSS, U.S. SECRETARY OF COMMERCE: Thank you for having me -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: So what is your expectation on this contempt issue?

ROSS: Oh, this is just more political theater. It doesn't really have any substantive basis. We produced to the committee over 14,000 pages of documents.

What's at issue here is about a dozen documents, roughly 15 pages, all of which the courts didn't find necessary to make their conclusion.

So this is silly. I testified myself for almost seven hours before this very committee. Three of my former senior staff people including one who is now assistant attorney general in the state of Florida, testified as well.

We answered thousands of questions. We are not stonewalling. But we are also not yielding on the very, very important matter of executive privilege. These are privileged documents. They're going to remain privilege documents. And we're not going to be frightened into changing that position just because of some action the House might take.

BARTIROMO: So how will the President deal with this then in terms of understanding fully the number of Americans in this country versus illegals? I mean is that the whole point of putting that question on the census?

ROSS: Well, the question of illegals was never going to be asked. The census was intending to ask the question are you a citizen or are you not.

BARTIROMO: Right.

ROSS: It never asked about legal status. Nor can the census data be used for ICE purposes or criminal investigation of any sort. Under Title 13, those data are protected. Individual data cannot be released. There's a serious jail sentence and a serious fine for anybody who is convicted of doing so.

BARTIROMO: Right. And the left knows that -- right Wilbur? But they don't want this question on the census regardless. Why do you think that is?

ROSS: Well, I think it's just gamesmanship on their part. They know we're going to come much closer to the answer than we ever have before.

BARTIROMO: I see.

ROSS: Because with the President's executive order, we're having much better access to federal documents than we ever had before. And believe it or not, many states are also going to be cooperating with us.

BARTIROMO: Ok.

ROSS: So we will get the kind of data that's needed and in some ways it will be even better because I believe that a lot of census money should be dedicated to administrative records, rather than just people ringing doorbells and we hope that the progress we make this time will move us toward that for the 2020 census.

BARTIROMO: Ok. Well, we're going to be watching that obviously.

Meanwhile, look what's going on in the Congress right now -- Secretary. I mean first of all, big tech is in the hot seat, lawmakers taking aim at Silicon Valley giants yesterday. The issues here -- data and privacy concerns.

Listen to this. I've got to get your reaction.

ROSS: Well, I was at the --

(CROSSTALKING)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SENATOR SHERROD BROWN (D), OHIO: Facebook dangerous. Now Facebook might not intend to be dangerous, but surely they don't respect the power of the technologies they're playing with. Like a toddler who has gotten his hands on a book of matches, Facebook has burned down the House over and over and called every arson a learning experience.

SENATOR MARSHA BLACKBURN (R), TENNESSEE: On Monday, you claimed in an op ed that Google is not politically biased, yet you acknowledge that Google took down or limited the reach of conservative content accounts and only did so mistakenly.

SENATOR JAMES RASKIN (D), MARYLAND: According to data produced by Rand Fishkin, Google controls over 90 percent of the search engine market in the United States. So congratulations on that. Although this seems to fit the classical definition of monopoly --

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: What about that? You know, it's interesting to look on both sides of the aisle, Secretary, and both sides of the aisle want to really put in the screws on these tech companies. What's your take?

ROSS: Well, I was at the social media conference last week at the White House and quite a number of the participants in that conference came up with very specific instances of censorship.

These are not theoretical issues. These are people saying this is exactly what happened to me on this date at this time. So there is censorship. I don't think there's any question based on the evidence that those folks put forward.

And so I think the real question is how should government, how should the congress, how should the administration deal with it. Because anybody who thinks there wasn't censorship is wrong. There was a public survey taken - - 13,000 something responses came in, mostly all giving instances of this kind of censorship.

BARTIROMO: Yes. So what is this administration going to do about it? I mean I spoke with President Trump just about, I don't know, two weeks ago or so when he called into the program and I said to him, look, do you want to see regulation here? Do you want to see -- how are you going to get these guys to stop doing what they're doing if in fact this is the reality? Because if you've seen the censorship of conservatives now, wait until we get knee-deep into 2020.

Here's what the President said to me two weeks ago. Watch this -- Secretary.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Mr. President -- you mentioned technology companies, how concerned are you that technology companies are censoring conservatives and they're going to do this right up to the 2020 election.

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Well, they're doing it to me on Twitter. I mean what they did to me on Twitter is incredible. You know, I have millions and millions of followers but I will tell you, they make it very hard for people to join me in Twitter and they make it very much harder for me to get out the message.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: And he went on to say, when I said to him do you want to see new regulation, said -- I said do you prefer just seeing competition in the marketplace. He said you might need legislation in order to get the competition.

ROSS: Well, that could be. This is a whole new area for us to explore. But I think the underlying question is it's not appropriate for this kind of censorship. They've been given a get out of jail free card by the Congress, saying that if you're not the creating media, you don't have certain responsibilities.

Well, to me, censorship is creating media, it's creating content, and if they're going to start doing that, they better think about the consequences.

BARTIROMO: All right. Let me switch gears, ask you about trade. Futures are higher this morning or mixed after the markets took a hit yesterday on President Trump's comments that a deal with China may still be out of reach.

Here's what the President said. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: We have a long way to go as far as tariffs with China is concerned if we want. We have another $325 billion that we can put a tariff on if we want. So we're talking to China about a deal. But I wish they didn't break the deal that we had.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: So is it fair to say it's probably a long time before we actually see deals here? What do you think, Secretary? Where are we?

ROSS: Well, as you know, I've said repeatedly this is not a 10-minute process.

BARTIROMO: Right.

ROSS: This is a long, involved process. The fundamental question now, though, is will they go back to the point where we were before they changed their mind and backtracked on some of the understandings that had been reached. That's the important issue right now.

And that's what's being probed in telephone conversations and the outcome of those phone conversations is what will help determine whether there is the next meeting and if so, when.

BARTIROMO: So you have any optimism or encouragement that they are planning to stop the theft of IP? Isn't that one of the big ticket items? Real quick.

ROSS: Well, the big ticket items are the structural reforms. The theft of IP, the unlevel playing field in procurement, the subsidies -- all those. But there's another in some ways even bigger issue. And that is, what is the U.S. enforcement capability in the event that they violate the agreement.

BARTIROMO: Right. Sure. Yes. You were talking about that before.

ROSS: That's the real key. That's the real key.

BARTIROMO: And real quick, before you go, Secretary -- on USMCA I was speaking to a high profile senator over the last week and he said I'm not expecting Nancy Pelosi to bring it to the floor at all.

ROSS: Well, it would be a real dereliction of duty if she did not. This is the biggest and the best trade deal this country has ever made. And it's quite ridiculous that many Democrats in the Congress voted for NAFTA. NAFTA was not only a disaster, but paragraph by paragraph USMCA is demonstrably better on all scores, particularly for U.S. manufacturing, but also for the digital economy, for intellectual property, for environmental and for labor constraints.

BARTIROMO: I know, but she doesn't want him to have another victory. We'll just have to wait and see.

Real quick before you go, Secretary -- there's a report that the President was considering removing you from your post following the Supreme Court defeat on adding the citizenship question to the census, according to NBC News. NBC is reporting this. What can you tell us?

ROSS: Well, I was on a trip with the President last Friday. We were in Milwaukee. We were in Cleveland. Was at the cabinet meeting of course yesterday and here I am on TV today. I think you ought to go by facts, not by rumors on some other network.

BARTIROMO: You got it. Mr. Secretary -- it's always a pleasure to see you. Thanks so much.

ROSS: Good to see you -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: We've covered a lot there. Wilbur Ross -- always a pleasure. Thank you, sir.

Coming up arrests at ICE headquarters, protesters blocking entrances and exits in a push to get rid of the agency over immigration and migrant detention. The fallout coming up.

Then celebrating the Apollo 11, Washington marks the golden anniversary with a high profile monument getting in on the act. All the beautiful pictures coming up. Back in a moment.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Welcome back to MORNINGS WITH MARIA. I'm Cheryl Casone with some headlines we're watching for you this morning.

It is official, European regulators are investigating Amazon. They're going to look at whether Amazon's use of other merchants' data breached E.U. rules. This investigation is going to focus on Amazon's standard agreements with marketplace sellers and whether the company uses their data unfairly.

Amazon says it will cooperate. There was a little of a hit in the stock this morning though. It is slightly lower in the premarket right now.

Taking a look at shares of Qualcomm, they are actually moving higher in the premarket, more than 5.5 percent right now. The Justice Department has asked a federal appeals court to pause the enforcement of an anti-trust ruling. The Justice department says it would be impossible to replace Qualcomm's role in 5G technology in the short term. Back in May a judge ruled that Qualcomm engaged in anti-competitive patent licensing practices and it ordered the company to license its technology to rival chip makers. We shall see where that court case goes though now.

And in honor of the 50th anniversary of the Apollo 11 mission to the moon, the Washington Monument is looking more like a rocket for the next two nights. Lok at this, it's pretty cool. The Smithsonian Institute is projecting a life size 363-foot image of a Saturn 5 rocket. That's accompanied by a 70-minute video presentation. If you're in the area, check it out.

All right. We've got a lot more coming up this morning.

Lawmakers grilling Facebook. The tech giant answering questions over its proposed digital currency. Their response coming up next.

Plus, free beer for life. Now I've got your attention, I'm assuming. Busch is offering customers the ultimate prize but they're going to have to work for it. Details coming up.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DAVID MARCUS, LIBRA CO-FOUNDER, FACEBOOK: We will take the time to get this right. We expect the review of Libra to be among the most extensive ever. We are fully committed to working with regulators here and around the world.

And let me be clear and unambiguous. Facebook will not offer the Libra digital currency until we have fully addressed regulators concerned and received appropriate approvals.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: That was David Marcus, head of Facebook's cryptocurrency Libra. The social network under fire on Capitol Hill this week. Lawmakers pushing for regulation over Libra over worries of instability and national security.

Joining us right now EY senior vice chairman Michael Inserra. And Michael -- it's great to have you this morning. Thanks so much for joining us.

MICHAEL INSERRA, SENIOR VICE CHAIRMAN, EY: Thank you -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: What's your reaction to what you say on Capitol Hill and the longer term outlook for whether it's block chain or coins? how do you see this developing?

INSERRA: Look, I think you have to look at this in the context of as you just said the bigger picture. Things like block chain are here to stay and they're actually moving at a much more accelerated pace. You know, 20 years ago when ERP systems came into play, people were unclear how that was going to revolutionize.

This is a whole different element. It is a secure payment system. It actually has no central authority. And we're actually big believers in things like public block chain.

And much of what you saw in the testimony is a consortium of 28 companies. It's not just a single company that I think really is recognizing things need to change. But we do need the right regulatory and oversight. I think you heard it resoundingly. You know, you don't want unintended consequences. But this isn't going away.

BARTIROMO: So don't be confused by the upset over Facebook and Libra because the block chain technology is much different and that's sort of the backdrop and here to stay.

INSERRA: Yes, exactly. Go ahead.

CAFARO: I was just going to say but the issue with Facebook is not going away and you know, we just heard the gentleman, you know, basically say to Congress, look, we're not going to move forward unless we address the regulators' concerns.

And I just recently saw an article, I believe it was in the "Washington Post" talking about the fact that Facebook actually preemptively went and presented this information to the Treasury as well as the SEC. And they were apparently the -- the SEC was stunned that Facebook was unable to answer some basic questions about concerns surrounding money laundering and consumer protection.

And so how are they really going to address some of these concerns? I mean are they really prepared. Or, you know, are we really seeing something like Libra being, you know, pushed further out because it's going to take so much longer to address the concerns of the regulators?

INSERRA: So LOOK, let me take block chain just for a moment to a different place and what is block chain.

BARTIROMO: That's right. We're talking about two different things.

INSERRA: Two different things here.

BARTIROMO: Right. Sure.

INSERRA: Let me talk about why I think block chain is here to stay. And it's been around for 10 years. But some of the things it does -- it is really an end to end, very secure payment type system. Ok. It's almost a distributed ledger so that any person on the block chain --

CAFARO: And the coins are the currency.

INSERRA: And the coins. Now, I also want to make a distinguishment between bitcoin and cryptocurrencies and the currencies that are talked about here which are actually backed by financial reserves. Ok.

So again, sometimes it's the headline that kind of disrupts the actual reality of it. But let me just talk about some things that we're doing in block chain that I think are fascinating.

It's tokenizing or tracking better things around the world. It could be viruses and knowing where patient zero exists today. It could be containers, billions of containers move around the world in cargo, marine block chain. Being able to actually hone in on where a source of food emanated from and a problem with that food is done in manual, very archaic ways.

BARTIROMO: And it has nothing to do with Libra or Facebook.

INSERRA: And that's why I wanted, Maria -- to stay focused on that.

BARTIROMO: I'm glad you did that. That was really articulate the way that you explained and made it so accessible.

NARDELLI: Yes. It's very -- as we talk here -- like very educational to a lot of us out there. We hadn't heard about block chain for a while. It kind of has gone into the background. But I know, Michael -- you and EY are very dominant in that with your innovation centers, with you know, advanced manufacturing, et cetera, et cetera.

You want to talk a little about what you're -- you returned from a global trip. So you've had the benefit of globality, if you can bring it to our audience today.

INSERRA: Well, you know, we talked a lot about why is unemployment at 3.6 yet we feel like there's these mixed wins. I think innovation, again, continues to create this efficacy of the marketplace that's allowing us to continue to propel the environment.

I think one of the big things we're focused on is how do large institutions maintain a day one mentality and entrepreneurial. More and more, it's start-ups are great, they're a critical part of the U.S. capitalist system but big institutions are adapting and becoming more agile. And they're doing it through the adventures that we've been helping them more and others are helping them work with which is really setting up innovation activities.

But that those that actually can permeate their broader organizational alignment. So really, you know, kind of segmenting the business and finding ways to accelerate innovation through it. I think that may be one of the unsung catalysts of this extended economic run.

NARDELLI: Yes.

BARTIROMO: All right. Michael -- great analysis. Thanks so much.

INSERRA: Great. Thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: Good to see you. Michael Inserra from EY joining us.

President Trump just tweeted about the Democrats. Here's what he said. The Democrats in Congress are getting nothing done, not on drug pricing, not on immigration, not on infrastructure. Not on nothing. So much opportunity yet all they want to do is go fishing. The American people are tired of never-ending witch hunts. They want results now," writes the President.

All right. We take a break.

When we come back, the new Trump administration asylum rules aimed at stopping migrants before they even reach the border with Mexico. All that coming up.

Customs and Border Patrol acting director Mark Morgan will weigh in next in an exclusive.

Then Elon Musk's next big idea, new details about his brain to machine interface. Wait until you see this -- next up.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Wednesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Wednesday, July 17th. Your top stories right now 7:32 a.m. on the East Coast.

Futures are indicating the markets will open higher this morning even it's just fractionally. Dow Futures are up just two points. The S&P struggling to hold in to positive territory and the NASDAQ up 6-1/2. It looks like we are seeing some selling right now because the markets are well off of the highs of the morning.

This on top of a pause yesterday of course. We had a record run. But yesterday markets took a breather, down 23 points on the Dow yesterday, S&P was down 10, and the NASDAQ was lower by 35.

In Europe this morning, major indices are mixed to lower. FT-100 down 19, CAC Quarante down nine, and the DAX Index in Germany lower by 23.

In Asia overnight, fears drove markets lower but here too fractional moves on a summer Tuesday.

Focus on earnings this morning, lots of big names reporting earnings for the second quarter. The banks are in the spotlight once again. Bank of America with a beat on adjusted revenue and earnings. The stock is down a fraction, but profits were rising on loan growth in the quarter.

Linking the brain directly to applications. Find out more about Elon Musk's latest venture.

And then, the quest for free beer but you will have to work for it. The details coming up on that.

All those stories coming up this Wednesday morning. But first, our top story this half an hour, battle at the border, the Trump administration lays out new asylum rules this week making migrants who pass through other countries on their way to the United States ineligible for asylum. They have to do asylum in those countries. The new regulations facing lawsuits from civil rights and immigrations groups. The president weighed in yesterday. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We were sending hundreds of millions of dollars to Guatemala and Honduras. We're not going to send it anymore. We were giving them hundreds of millions of dollars like fools for years. And all they did is send us up a lot of people, caused a lot of problems and a lot of the people in those caravans were criminals, hardened criminals, dangerous people. And why not? Why would Honduras or Guatemala or El Salvador, why would they keep their criminals when you can put them in to the caravan, lose them in a caravan, and send them up to the United States. We take everybody. Because the Democrats don't allow immigration laws that mean anything. It's horrible.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining me right now is U.S. Customs and Border Protection acting commissioner, Mark Morgan. And Mark, it is great to have you on the program this morning. Thanks so much for joining us.

MARK MORGAN, ACTING COMMISSIONER, U.S. CUSTOMS AND BORDER PROTECTION: You bet.

BARTIROMO: Do you agree with that? What the president just said? What is it about the Democrats that they are not agreeing with some of these issues that the president has spotlighted over the last couple of years, in terms of the crisis at the border?

MORGAN: You know, Maria, that's the $60,000 question that I've been asking for a long time and so have a lot of experts. And look, I look at this as a Congress issue. Congress needs to act on a bipartisan way to pass meaningful legislation to address the very real loopholes in our asylum that is causing this crisis. So I agree that Congress needs to act and if they do, they can fix this crisis.

BARTIROMO: Well, but the issue is they do not -- I mean, certainly the majority in the House does not want the president to have a victory. They just started calling it a crisis recently, they -- many are still not. They said it was a manufactured crisis by the president.

And then even when you go down to the border which I did and I actually witnessed it firsthand in El Paso, how horrible the situation is and the dangerous situation that children are being put in, you're still not getting the kind of -- you know, enthusiasm to actually make a change. When you say all you really need to do is change the asylum standards and the Flores Agreement.

MORGAN: Yes Maria, and you have been there. You saw it firsthand. Another example of that. I know that you witnessed the children being exploited.

BARTIROMO: I did.

MORGAN: And how emotional that was for you and it should be for all Americans. And in case in point, we were asking Congress for months to pass a supplemental because children, because families were being held in facilities that they shouldn't be.

BARTIROMO: But they're not doing it. So what's your plan B, Mark? How are you going to get your arms around this and this administration going to, you know, discourage these migrants from coming through Mexico to the border and flooding our borders and when you -- and it doesn't look like you're going to actually get a change from Congress.

MORGAN: That's right. And Maria, I think that's very important. So, we need to continue to work with Congress when we can. But we can't wait for them to do their job because they've shown they're not willing to do it.

And so, we are doing a lot. We're working with the government of Mexico and we're -- the migrant protection protocol for example that we're sending individuals back to wait in Mexico while they go through the asylum process. Today almost 20,000 individuals have now gone back to Mexico instead of clogging up our system.

And right now at the top of your show, you talked about the new regulation for asylum. That's an -- the American people need to understand, that's not new, that's an international standard. The European Union countries do this. Is that -- it's an accepted standard is that the first country that you come to, that's where you should be required to apply for asylum and that's what this new regulation is about.

BARTIROMO: Yes, let me ask about these ICE protests, Mark. Because federal authorities arrested 11 activists yesterday for blocking entrances and exits to ICE headquarters in Washington. I mean, this is really becoming such a scene. There was an armed man was killed after police -- after police -- after attacking an ICE detention center in Washington over the weekend, writing a manifesto to Antifa before carrying out the ambush.

Progressive Congresswomen and members of the squad, Ilhan Omar, Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez not speaking out to condemn Antifa at all. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Do you condemn Antifa? Will you condemn Antifa for the attack in Washington?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: So there you go. They're making all this noise in the spotlight, being talked about across the news media, and yet it's -- I mean, what is this? Is this smoke and mirrors? They're asked a specific question, will you condemn Antifa. And they refuse to do it.

MORGAN: So, it's very frustrating. In that manifesto he actually mentions someone from Congress, specific language and rhetoric they have used. Now, don't get me wrong. I don't -- those are actions individuals. I'm not putting that on anybody on Congress.

But I think what's important is, the Congress should recognize stop the rhetoric, stop attacking the men and women of ICE and CBP for doing their statutory responsible mission. That they're enforcing the laws that Congress have enacted.

So, if Congress doesn't like the current laws, they need to change it. And what I would say to people that want to protest ICE or CBP, I would say your protests are being directed towards the wrong people. If you don't like the laws, then go petition Congress to change the laws and we will enforce those laws. It's very frustrating to see.

And as you said, Maria, it's -- that violence and that rhetoric, it's not helping, it's not solving the crisis.

BARTIROMO: Well, you also have companies like, you know, Wayfair, saying, we're not going to -- we're not going to send any more beds to the detention centers. We don't like what's going on. Well, who are you hurting? I mean, no wonder there's 900 people behind bars when they're supposed to be 385 and they're so busting out of the accommodations because there's so many people. I mean, who are you hurting not to send beds? It's just crazy.

How about this new immigration proposal, Mark. The White House adviser, Jared Kushner, also weighing in here. Presenting an updated plan to the Trump Cabinet, Congressional aides could see it this week. What are you expecting?

MORGAN: So, I'm expecting the same thing that I've been expecting Congress to do that hasn't happened, is that -- is that we actually put forth some meaningful legislation that's actually going to address the issues.

Senator Lindsey Graham is trying to put forth a bill too that will address the specific issues that could absolutely, positively impact this crisis. We can't sit on our hands anymore. We can't allow this crisis to continue to go. Something has to be done. So I support any legislation that's going forward that actually is meaningful legislation that will address this crisis.

BARTIROMO: I know that part of the issue is that the CBP officers are being forced to do other things and not even stay at their post because of all of these kids showing up who are sick, they're taking babies to hospitals and checking on children and cleaning babies and all this stuff when in fact they should be at their post, securing the borders.

MORGAN: That's exactly right, Maria. Now, we have two elements. We have Border Patrol agents and then officers from the office of field operation. All those resources are being pulled away from the port of entry and from the line to really do the humanitarian mission.

BARTIROMO: Right.

MORGAN: We have individuals that are feeding babies, they're changing diapers, that are ordering baby formula, water and it goes on and on. Up to -- up to 50 percent of our resources are pulled off the line to do the humanitarian mission.

So, Maria, make no mistake, our country is less safe because of this crisis going on because that enables the cartels to take advantage of those loopholes and that the wide open border, bad things, bad people are getting through every day.

BARTIROMO: All right, Mark, we will keep watching the story and it is an important one. Thank you so much.

MORGAN: You bet, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Mark Morgan, joining u there.

Coming up, artificial intelligence in your brain? The new technology Elon Musk says is the future of human interaction.

TheN, the hunt for beer, Busch makes an official loyal customers cannot refuse. But they'll have to work to win the ultimate prize, details after this.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. El Chapo will learn his fate today. Cheryl Casone on headlines now, Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Well, Maria, Mexican drug lord Joaquin Guzman is going to appear in Brooklyn federal court today where a judge is expected to sentence the convicted drug lord to life behind bars. The hearing could be his last chance to speak publicly. He was convicted in February in an epic drug trafficking case. Guzman accused of smuggling mountains of cocaine into the United States over a 25-year period. He claims he was framed by traffickers working for the government. Well, Elon Musk's updated Neuralink has been unveiled. The project focused on developing brain, machine interfaces. The new version includes flexible threads that are less likely to damage the brain than the materials currently used. Neuralink has been developing brain machine interfaces to connect humans and computers. Musk says that the system has been tested on a monkey that was able to control a computer with its brain.

And how about some free beer for life? Well, it can happen, but you're going to need some hiking boots. Busch not making this easy. They're hiding a pop-up bar in a national forest for just one day this Saturday. Clues are revealed out on Twitter. You get free merchandise. But the winner gets a lifetime supply of beer.

Here's the thing, Busch is going to plant a hundred trees in our national forest for each person who finds the pop-up shop. We should add that there's a hundred and -- what, 50 national forests across the country. But anyway, good luck to all of you.

BARTIROMO: Great. Thank you, Cheryl.

CASONE: You bet.

BARTIROMO: Coming up, Beyond Meat moves, the maker of the world's first plant based burger expanding its reach with some key connections. We've got the details after we -- after this.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Let's take a look at Futures, higher this morning but really back and forth, not a lot of commitment. Dow Futures up five points, S&P up a fraction, and the NASDAQ Futures up six on top of a lower day yesterday, really the markets took a breather on the record run.

And joining us right now to talk more about markets and the economy, is the chairman and CEO of Strategas, Jason Trennert. (INAUDIBLE) Jason, it's great to see you.

JASON TRENNERT, CHAIRMAN AND CEO, STRATEGAS: Great to be here.

BARTIROMO: Thanks so much for joining us. So what's your take on the broader backdrop of the economy? We have the ECB doing a meeting on July 25th. And then the two day meeting, the Fed, the 31st where there is obviously 90 percent chance the Fed lowers interest rates.

TRENNERT: Right, I think, well, the first thing I would say is the Fed has to -- in my opinion, the Fed has to ease now, given where market expectations are. It would be too big a shock to the system if they didn't. I think it also highlights the idea that Bob and I were talking before, it's not a closed system. The Fed really can't go it alone. It can't be an island. If you have $13 trillion worth of negative yield, the sovereign debt globally, there's a -- there's a limit to how much the Fed can tighten. And it's found that out the hard way twice in the last three years. So the Fed in some ways just has to get a little bit back more towards a more of an international standard.

My opinion, it's too bad because using monetary policy alone as the single tool creates a lot of distortions in the economy and not particularly a great way to run the economy, but it's very good for financial assets. It's not as good for the economy as a result.

BARTIROMO: Have you -- have you ever seen anything like this whereas you know, the economy is doing really well, 51-year low in unemployment. And yet the Fed has to cut rates because every other central bank in the world is cutting rates and the currency situation puts the U.S. at a disadvantage.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA: Well, I think some people point to 1995 and 1998 where the Fed's trying to get ahead of a potential slowdown. But when you do think about this, if they are able to revive growth here, give us a little bit of a boost, and then also potentially ease the situation abroad, where do you put your money? What looks most attractive? Because the U.S. has run its -- the S&P 500 trading at a premium multiple. You look at Europe, there's a lot wrong over there. And then Asia easing should probably actually help the emerging markets.

TRENNERT: I tend to agree with the emerging markets call. And I actually -- I have more of a bias towards cyclical as we go into 2020 for a variety of reasons. But one of the things, and the president may kind of stick the landing here in terms of I don't know if this is part of the plan or whether -- you know, whether it's luck or but it looks like you're going to get a Fed easing and a resolution of the trade tensions in the second half of this year.

BARTIROMO: Do you think so?

TRENNERT: I think so. And I mainly because I think it's politically expedient to have some sort of resolution of the trade tensions.

And so, you set yourself up for a pretty strong economy going into the election next year. We wrote a piece, you know, a couple months ago saying it wasn't real -- a really a strong incentive for the president to resolve trade tensions earlier this year. Because there I think there were concerns, I don't know this for a fact within the White House, the economy was peaking too early from a political point of view.

BARTIROMO: The date and work -- the date and work.

TRENNERT: Yes, I know I could. I mean, if you -- if you have the economy you have now in October of next year, regardless of what you think of the president, it's -- he'd be tough to beat.

CAPRI CAFARO, EXECUTIVE RESIDENT, AMERICAN UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF PUBLIC AFFAIRS: Well, there's some things the president has under his control and others he doesn't in regard to trade. So say for example the China trade war is quote, unquote, resolved, yet Congress doesn't act on USMCA, what happens under a scenario like that?

TRENNERT: Well, that's a --

BARTIROMO: That's a good question.

TRENNERT: No, it's a very good question. It certainly doesn't help. I would also say the president though generally speaking has -- I think the people tend to underestimate some of the executive powers --

CAFARO: Sure.

TRENNERT: -- that the president does have to make other deals, non -- you know, remove non-trade barriers, do other things.

There are other things that are being talked about like indexing capital gains to inflation. I don't know if you've heard that. But that's another thing that the administration has been talking about to lift equity prices.

So, it's true, the president doesn't have complete control but he probably has a little bit more control than people might give him credit for. And - -

CAFARO: Are we going to play a lot of games with chain CPI in general?

TRENNERT: Yes.

BOB NARDELLI, FORMER CEO, CHRYSLER AND HOME DEPOT: Well, he's talking to North Korea, now he's open to talk to Iran. I mean, there are number of things to your point that I think he's got a number of levers in that cockpit of his that he'll be able to make sure that things are moving in the right direction in November. But as we were talking earlier, even if the rate comes down a quarter point, it's still the most attractive rate globally with this $13 trillion.

TRENNERT: That's right.

NARDELLI: So, we're still going to see a lot of foreign currency come in. We talked earlier about the long, short portfolio, shorts are gone, right? So, back to the question, where do we put our money?

TRENNERT: Yes, no, listen, I like -- personally, I like cyclicals in the United States. So, we're overweight financials, industrials, technology stocks, we also have REITs in there, but that's more to get some income.

But I think the most unloved part of the market is really the most cyclical part of the market. One of the problems when you have very low interest rates is that things with yield and things without yield become very expensive. So, collectible art becomes very expensive and utilities trade at 22 times earnings. You know, that are growing at two or three percent a year. And that's not particularly -- in my opinion, that's not particularly attractive.

The places that are more attractive now would be, again, places like financials but places that people really don't like, industrials would be another one because of some of the trade tensions.

So, within the U.S., I like that, I like emerging markets. Europe we were talking before. I don't -- you know, the idea that the ECB might be forced to buy equities, to me is a -- it might work. I mean, certainly stocks would go up. But to me, that's not the most compelling, it's not a great reason to buy European equities aside from a trade.

BARTIROMO: Yes I brought it up because Rick Rieder from BlackRock was here last week and said, look, the ECB is going to be buying European equities, I want to buy European equities. So, we'll see about that, but you're right, Europe's not generating any growth.

Real quick, Cap expending, has it come back? What do you -- what do you think about cap expending?

TRENNERT: The problem with CapEx, there's certainly enough cash flow to go around, but the problem is that I do think -- and to be fair, the administration has created a problem in which all the pieces were there but then if you follow up the big tax cut that's very, very stimulating for CapEx with the trade war, it's very difficult for -- you know, it's very difficult to have that confidence. We have someone here that would know, that, you know, it's easier just to issue bonds and buy back stock.

BARTIROMO: Yes, a lot of uncertainty. Jason, great to see you.

TRENNERT: Great to be here.

BARTIROMO: Thanks so much. Jason Trennert. We'll be right back.
