urn:contentItem:608G-H1G1-JB20-G2HM-00000-00Focus On Jobs, Coronavirus And Stimulus; NASDAQ Hits Another Record High; Vaccine Optimism Grows; Father Of Teen Killed In Seattle's CHOP Zone Speaks Out; Delta Airlines Says, Flyers Must Wear A Mask Or Face Ban; Atlantic City Casinos Reopen To The Public Today; Smoking And Drinking in Casinos Banned During Reopening; Indoor Dining Pushed Back Due to COVID-19 Cases Spike; New Jersey Will Not Allow Indoor Dining As Part Of Reopening; Telehealth Industry Exploding Amid Coronavirus; Groundbreaking Telehealth Program Uses Television To Reach More Americans; Telehealth Industry Exploding Amid Coronavirus; Sarah Jessica Parker To Launch Dating Show On Lifetime; 55 percent Of Americans Were More Stressed In May Than January; NASA's Outer Space Perfume Preparing For Launch2020-07-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:51:22ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA6:00 AM ESTJim Allen, Tom Conroy, Joanie Courtney, Steve Moore, Stephen Auth, Brian Brenberg, Joanie Courtney, Jim McLaughlinNEWSFinancial070201cb.231Focus On Jobs, Coronavirus And Stimulus; NASDAQ Hits Another Record High; Vaccine Optimism Grows; Father Of Teen Killed In Seattle's CHOP Zone Speaks Out; Delta Airlines Says, Flyers Must Wear A Mask Or Face Ban; Atlantic City Casinos Reopen To The Public Today; Smoking And Drinking in Casinos Banned During Reopening; Indoor Dining Pushed Back Due to COVID-19 Cases Spike; New Jersey Will Not Allow Indoor Dining As Part Of Reopening; Telehealth Industry Exploding Amid Coronavirus; Groundbreaking Telehealth Program Uses Television To Reach More Americans; Telehealth Industry Exploding Amid Coronavirus; Sarah Jessica Parker To Launch Dating Show On Lifetime; 55 percent Of Americans Were More Stressed In May Than January; NASA's Outer Space Perfume Preparing For LaunchMaria Bartiromo, Cheryl Casone, Lou Dobbs

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KAYLEIGH MCENANY, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: Law and order has prevailed, and Seattle has been liberated from the anarchist. In President Trump's America, autonomous zones will have no sanctuary.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LOU DOBBS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Kayleigh McEnany. And that's it for us tonight. We thank you for being with us. Judicial Watch--

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning. Happy Thursday, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is jobs day, Thursday, July 2nd. Your top stories right now, 6:00 a.m. on the button on the East Coast.

Jobs in America this morning. The June jobs report is out at 8:30 a.m. Eastern. Economists are expecting a gain in jobs of 3 million jobs. The unemployment rate is expected to fall to 12.3 percent. We have full coverage this morning of jobs report for the month of June.

Coronavirus cases, meanwhile, spiking at a record rate. More than 50,000 new cases reported in the U.S. yesterday alone. This as more states and businesses, including McDonald's and Apple, roll back those reopening. There is some promising news on the development of a vaccine this morning.

Meanwhile, markets are pointing to a higher opening this morning. Take a look at Futures. They are looking higher as investors keep a close eye on jobs, the virus, and the possibility of more stimulus as this holiday shortened week nears an end.

Dow Industrials this morning up 223 points. The NASDAQ up 44, and the S&P 500 up 18 points. This after the third quarter kicked off with a mixed day yesterday, the NASDAQ scoring its 22nd record close of the year, with another gain of 95 points at 4 o'clock on Wall Street yesterday.

Meanwhile, more stimulus ahead. President Trump telling Fox Business he supports additional money going directly into Americans' pockets. He's looking to add incentives to get people back to work - just a warning of a market crash if Former Vice President Joe Biden gets elected.

The House takes action over China's crackdown on Hong Kong's freedoms, meanwhile, voting to sanction bank suing business with Chinese officials who are involved in implementing that security law. It has already led to hundreds of arrests in Hong Kong overnight although that even impacts Americans in the city. All that coming up.

Officials finally taking action in Seattle, meanwhile, clearing out the autonomous zone after three weeks of occupation. And then there is Tesla driving to new heights, charging past its competition, now the largest automaker by market value, also surpassing other big names like Disney and Coca-Cola.

"Mornings with Maria" is live right now.

Global markets this morning look like this. As you see, we are looking at gains across the board. There are growing hopes for a coronavirus vaccine that is pushing markets higher in Europe this morning. Pfizer and BioNTech announced promising data from its vaccine tests. We've got more on that coming up.

FT 100 is up 50 points, the CAC quarante in Paris is up 78, and the DAX Index is up 227 points. Encouraging vaccine news also drove markets in Asia overnight. Take a look at the Asian markets, and you see we've got money moving into stocks there as well. Best performer was Hong Kong, up almost 3 percent on the Hang Seng Index.

Now, some of the top stories that we are watching this morning. President Trump says he supports coronavirus stimulus payments larger than $1,200 as long as it's done properly. Democrats have called for another round of $1,200 payments. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell says a potential phase four would be approved this month.

Coronavirus cases now spiking across the country with single-day numbers topping 50,000 for the first time. California, Texas, Arizona, North Carolina, and Georgia, all reported their highest infection totals to-date yesterday. The surge in cases forcing some states to roll back the reopening plans. California Governor Gavin Newsom is reversing the state's plan to reopen, ending indoor operations for businesses, including restaurants, in 19 counties. He's also forcing bars to shut down completely.

New York City, meanwhile, also delaying the return of indoor dining right now. McDonald's pausing the reopening of dine-in services as well, all the dine-in services in the United States for 21 days as coronavirus cases grow. Right now, only about 1,000 of its 14,000 locations have reopened, with reduced seating capacity.

The pandemic now cutting into the NFL pre-season, the league expected to officially cut the number of games from four to two. The league reportedly considering making fans sign a liability waiver as protection against lawsuits related to coronavirus.

And police in Hong Kong moving quickly to crack down on prodemocracy protestors under this controversial new national security law. Nearly 400 people were arrested overnight on the anniversary of Britain's handover of Hong Kong to China, including 10 people for violating the new law aimed at crushing dissent, potential jail time for life.

Secretary of State Mike Pompeo calling the measure, quote, "an affront to all nations," adding the United States will pursue efforts to end Hong Kong's special trading status. The Senate, meanwhile, is expected to vote on a bill that would sanction banks that do business with Chinese officials who are carrying out this new legislation. The House passed its own bill yesterday.

And markets pointing to a gain ahead of the last trading day before the holiday weekend this morning. It is jobs day in America. The June jobs report due out at 8:30 a.m. Eastern this morning. Estimates call for 3 million jobs additionally added to the economy in the month of June, as the economy rebounds from coronavirus shutdowns. The unemployment rate expected to fall to 12.3 percent.

Joining me right now is Federated Hermes' Chief Investment Officer, Stephen Auth. Also joining the conversation this morning is The King's College Business and Finance Chairman and Fox News contributor, Brian Brenberg; former Wall Street Journal Editorial Board member and "Trumponomics" co- author Stephen Moore; and EmployBridge Chief Workforce Analyst, Joanie Courtney. Great to see you everybody this morning. Thank you so much for being here.

STEPHEN MOORE, FORMER WSJ EDITORIAL BOARD MEMBER: Morning.

STEPHEN AUTH, FEDERATED HERMES CHIEF INVESTMENT OFFICER: Thank you.

BRIAN BRENBERG, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Morning.

JOANIE COURTNEY, EMPLOYBRIDGE CHIEF WORKFORCE ANALYST: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: And Steven Auth, let me kick it off with you. Of course, we have these new concerns now about the spikes - 50,000 spikes just in a day across the country. What's your take on the impact of the reopenings and the growth in stocks?

AUTH: Maria, I think what people are really looking at is deaths. And so far, as you know, that has not been nearly as dramatic as the increase in infections. So the operating theory of the markets is the people who feel safer and probably are, are the ones going on about and getting tested and maybe working through the virus. I think the country wants to do that.

Our death infection rates in the U.S. have been much lower than Europe - other than New York, which has been very tough. But that's what the market is watching, I would say, in terms of its outlook on the corona impact. But it's not going to be perfect coming through here.

I mean, we are going to see rising infection rates. Let's hope the treatment protocols, the profile of the people getting infected, et cetera, keep that tamp down in terms of real downside risk to individuals, which is what I think most people are focused on. But we're going to watch that.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I think this is a good--

AUTH: But that's one reason why it could be a little dicey in the second half, I think.

BARTIROMO: A little dicey in the second half because it's a good explainer to understand, even with these cases, you've got record valuations on Wall Street. The NASDAQ reached another record high. It's the 22nd all-time high for the year.

The S&P 500 also finished higher yesterday, as Tesla reached a milestone market cap of nearly $210 billion. This makes Tesla the most valuable automotive company in the world, more valuable than Coca-Cola, Disney, ExxonMobil, others. It's pretty extraordinary valuation. So what do you say about valuations out there in the face of all of this?

AUTH: Well, I've put out a piece last week, Maria. You may know that. We cut back our overweight. We are probably a little out over our skis down at the lowest with that really big overweight in stocks. We've cut it back quite a bit. We're still overweight a little bit.

But - the winners are pricey, the losers are pricey, and the survivors are dicey. And we're now looking around in the survivors and we're hanging onto our winners, but it's hard to add to them here, Maria. I mean, these are the winners of the post-corona world. They were the winners coming in. That's now accelerated.

But I think the big tech stocks - my view would be, these things have to take a little bit of a rest. I mean, they'll grow into their earnings. They're looking pretty solid in terms of growth. But it's hard for me to be screening by on those names here in the back half of the year, particularly with the political risks in front of us along with this--

BARTIROMO: Yes.

AUTH: --kind of bumpy recovery out of the corona, which is not going to be perfect either. So--

BARTIROMO: Yes. I want to ask you about the political risk with the election in the second half of the year. But let me bring in Brian Brenberg here.

Go ahead, Brian.

BRENBERG: Yes. Stephen, the story over the past month has been an economy that looks like a V-shaped recovery is possible. I still think that's the case. I think stocks are reflecting that. But you've got this overhang of governors and mayors now talking about rollbacks of reopening.

I don't think the American public wants to go for that, but how do you see that playing into valuations here? Are stocks going to believe what Americans are showing them or what mayors and governors are threatening right now?

AUTH: I would guess more of the former, Brian. I - the American people want to get restarted. And the governors are going to try to do the right thing to kind of slow things down and not make it (inaudible). There's no governor in this country that's going to shut down their state again. I think that's out of the question. People will be watching on the capital. But it is going to be a little bit bumpy.

I wrote - from V to U, or - we're exiting the V, entering the U. It's going to be more bumpy from here. We've got this sharp V off the lows as the industrial, the housing side really came on strong and are coming on strong. But the retail side of this economy, the bricks and mortar, the restaurants, the travel and leisure, these are going to go a little slower, and there's still pain left in those sectors. So I don't think we're going to get a V straight through the rest of the year here.

BARTIROMO: Well, there's certainly uncertainty going into the election. That's one of the key issues for the second half.

Stephen, let me ask you this. Market has performed well, I assume, partly due on the policies of this administration - lower taxes, lower regulation, et cetera. If the - does the market believe that that's going to continue, do you think, or our investors thinking maybe Joe Biden wins and that would mean Elizabeth Warren as the key economic voice? Whether she's Treasury Secretary or in the Senate, that's going to mean probably higher taxes and perhaps more regulation. Do markets trade down on that?

AUTH: Well, it's - I don't think it's good news for markets. I mean, he - I think the President should be calling Biden tax-and-regulate-Joe as opposed to sleepy-Joe. Sleepy-Joe is actually - half the country would prefer at this point. So there are offsetting positives to Biden presidency, Maria, that - I think we've got to acknowledge is, one, the country could use less tweets and little more calm out of the Oval Office. They're going to get that with Biden.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

AUTH: The Fed is going to try to offset whatever tax and regulate policies that come through. But we're talking - I think the market is only starting to look at the fairly radical progressive agenda of a Biden presidency. Capital gains, tax rates going up, ordinary tax rates on small businesses and high net worth individuals going up. Regulations going up.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

AUTH: That's all going to slow the growth trajectory. For us, we would have to take down our long-term growth trajectory and make stocks a little bit valuable, but there will be other offsetting pauses. I don't think the market is going to crash. And the market is already starting to assume that Biden is going to win. I think they think they're going to hold the Senate. My guess is that if--

BARTIROMO: OK.

AUTH: --if Biden does win, the Senate goes with it.

BARTIROMO: All right. We will keep watching that, obviously.

Stephen, it's good to see you this morning. Thank you so much, sir.

AUTH: Yes. Thank you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Have a good Independence Day weekend to you, Stephen Auth. Happy 4th of July. Thank you so much.

We are just getting started this morning. Coming up, Hard Rock International Chairman James Allen is here on Atlantic City's casinos, as they open their doors today.

And then in the 7:00 a.m. hour, we are taking a look at the "Word on Wall Street". Top analysts weigh in on the trading day ahead and the holiday weekend coming up, and of course, the second half.

Texas Congressman and medical doctor, Michael Burgess, is here on future stimulus and the surge in the COVID-19 cases in this home state. Union Square Hospitality CEO Danny Meyer joining us this morning on the New York City restaurant industry as it faces that pause in reopening.

And then at 8:00 a.m., we've got Georgia Senator David Perdue talking about coronavirus and its impact. Don't miss that. A lot to come. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Blockbuster fundraising in the race for the White House. Joe Biden and the Democratic National Committee bringing in a record $141 million last month and $282 million for the second quarter. Biden's fundraiser topping President Trump and the RNC. The Republicans ranking in $131 million last month and $266 million for the second quarter.

Joining us right now is the pollster for the Trump 2020 Presidential Campaign and McLaughlin & Associates President and Partner, Jim McLaughlin.

Great to see you, Jim. Thanks so much for joining us.

JIM MCLAUGHLIN, POLLSTER FOR TRUMP 2020 PRESIDENTIAL CAMPAIGN & MCLOUGHLIN AND ASSOCIATES PRESIDENT AND PARTNER: Great to be here, Maria.

BARTIROMO: I want to ask you about polling and about how it's done differently. But first, let me get your reaction to those fundraising numbers, Biden versus Trump.

MCLAUGHLIN: The Democrats always raise lots of money. But the beautiful thing is this race isn't going to come down to money. If we all remember four years ago, Hillary Clinton significantly outraised this. She raised over a billion dollars. But there's no doubt in my mind that the Trump campaign--

BARTIROMO: Wow! Forgot about that.

MCLAUGHLIN: Yes. She raised - think about that. She raised over a billion dollars. Now, the great thing about that, though, is--

BARTIROMO: It's unbelievable.

MCLAUGHLIN: --Donald Trump doesn't need as much money as the Democrats do because nobody knows how to get his message out there better than Donald Trump.

BARTIROMO: So you look at all these polls. It's Fox News poll, a lot of different polls saying that the President is trailing Joe Biden. Before you comment on that, tell me how polling is done today. What is the situation in terms of polling in a COVID world? And even in the last couple of years, has polling changed in terms of how you do it? Do you do it on the internet, do you do it on phones, how do you poll?

MCLAUGHLIN: You do it all of the above. You do it on the internet, you do it on phones. But one of the big problems with a lot of these national polls that are out there, and I tell folks all the time, these national polls are really meaningless when it comes to the Presidential election. We saw that four years ago.

For instance, somebody like "The New York Times" about a week before Election Day, they were telling us there was a 92 percent chance that Hillary Clinton was going to become President.

One of the other big problems you have with the national polls is about a third of the people they're talking to in, what I call, the big eight Democratic states like Illinois, New York, California, they don't matter in the Presidential election.

What matters is those 17 battleground states right now. And if we remember back then, you had four years ago, folks were telling us there was that faint blue wall, Pennsylvania, Wisconsin and Michigan. There was no way that President Trump could win in those states. Well, we all know what happened on Election Day. He won all three of those states.

And a recent poll just came out in Wisconsin where President Trump was ahead, and another poll in Pennsylvania where the President is tied. So that's what you want to see. You want to see likely voters and you want to see folks - you want to see polls that are in the battleground states.

BARTIROMO: So, do you think that the polls that were showing Donald Trump trailing Joe Biden are wrong then? Are they not capturing the true vote?

MCLAUGHLIN: I don't think there's any doubt they're not capturing the true vote, Maria. And again, one of the problems is they're doing registered voters. They're not doing likely voters. And - but what's really interesting too is on the issue that's probably going to matter most come election day, rebuilding the economy, getting people back to work, you saw that even in the Fox News polls, which weren't great for President Trump--

BARTIROMO: That's right.

MCLAUGHLIN: --but he still had the advantage on the economy and jobs.

BARTIROMO: I want to talk about policy. I'm going to bring in Steve Moore on this because President Trump is going after Joe Biden's tax plan, weighing in on the election in an exclusive interview with Fox Business. Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT, UNITED STATES OF AMERICA: If he got elected, that's an overhang over the market because the market would crash - would absolutely crash. Market would go down by a tremendous amount. He'd raise taxes. He'd raise regulations.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: So, Joe Biden has said that. And certainly, if Elizabeth Warren is his treasury secretary, we're talking about a wealth tax. Obviously taxes are going to go up under a Biden administration, all taxes. And then there's the regulatory environment as well. What impact is that going to have on the economy? And then I want to bring Steve Moore in to talk about Trump's ideas as well. Real quick.

MCLAUGHLIN: Yes. Real quick. Just to tell you--

BARTIROMO: Go ahead, Jim.

MCLAUGHLIN: --what's the first - what's the first thing that Joe Biden said he was going to do when he became President? He's going to raise taxes. And intuitively, the voters will tell you, raising taxes hurts the economy, costs us jobs. I guess it's kind of like the Larry Kudlow messaging - the Larry Kudlow, Stephen Moore messaging.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCLAUGHLIN: When you raise taxes--

BARTIROMO: Right.

MCLAUGHLIN: --voters know it's bad for them.

BARTIROMO: All right. Real quick. Steve Moore, what is the President going to do in a second term?

MOORE: Well, look, more of the same. More tax cuts, more deregulation, more pro-America free trade deals. And the problem I think, Jim, is that - look, Trump has to have a huge lead. He should be beating Biden by 20 points in terms of who can best handle the economy. And I think, ultimately, don't you, Jim, that when people go to the polls in November in these shaky economic times that that might be the most important question voters ask themselves as who do you trust more on the economy?

MCLAUGHLIN: No doubt about it.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCLAUGHLIN: And the race hasn't been defined yet. And once that race is defined and the differences on the issues when it comes to taxes and regulations, Donald Trump is going to have a clear advantage.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll keep watching, Jim. Thank you so much for being here. Jim McLaughlin joining us there on polling.

Coming up, more stimulus is in the works. President Trump telling Fox Business about the possible cash coming your way. And then, place your bets, Atlantic City casinos are reopening today. How they plan to keep gamblers and workers safe? Right after this. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. The next round of stimulus, President Trump indicating to Fox Business yesterday that the next wave of relief could deliver more than the additional $1,200 floated by Democrats. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BLAKE BURMAN, FOX BUSINESS WASHINGTON CORRESPONDENT: Another round of direct payments for individuals. Do you support that at this time?

TRUMP: I do. I support it, but it has to be done properly. And I support actually larger numbers than the Democrats, but it's got to be done properly. We had something where they wanted, where it gave you a disincentive to work last time. And it was still money going to people and helping people. So I was all for that. But we want to create a very great incentive to work. So we're working on that, and I'm sure we'll all come together.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Republicans are criticizing the unemployment expansion saying that it encourages people to stay home rather than go back to work. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell vowing Tuesday to abandon the boost as part of the next round of relief.

Steve Moore, what do you expect from the next round of stimulus? What should it look like? I know there's a major issue with people working from home and saying, look, I'm making more money as I stay at home, why would I want to go back?

MOORE: Yes. This is the key issue in this phase four. And I was actually so pleased to hear that interview with Blake yesterday with the President. He nailed it. Whatever we do in phase four, we cannot keep these incentives for people to stay out of the labor force.

Maria, the Congressional Budget Office estimates that over four out of five Americans would make more money not working under the Pelosi plan than working. That would be catastrophic. In fact, I have a piece in the "Wall Street Journal" tomorrow with Casey Mulligan, one of the best labor economists in the country.

We estimate that if you allowed people to continue to get these super-high unemployment benefits, Maria, that would reduce employment this year by 10 million people. So, if Trump were to allow that to happen, there is no way he could get reelected because we couldn't have an expansion.

Republicans have to draw the line and say we are not going to have a policy that pays people more not to work than to work. And by the way, the one policy out there that pays people more to work, obviously, is the payroll tax reduction, and I really believe - my sources on Capitol Hill and the White House are saying, that's very much on the table.

BARTIROMO: Yes. The President told me that as well, that that's what he would like to see happen, a payroll tax holiday. Your idea.

All right. Take a quick break and then place your bet. So Atlantic City casinos are rolling the dice this morning, reopening today. The plan is to keep gamblers and workers safe. Coming up. You are watching "Mornings with Maria" live on Fox Business.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NEWS ANCHOR: Welcome back. A good Thursday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is jobs day, Thursday, July 2nd.

Let's take a look at where market stands 6:31 A.M. on the East Coast. We are looking at a higher opening to the broader averages this morning. Check out Futures indicating 200-point rally right of the gate for the Dow Industrials, about 1 percent. The NASDAQ is up 34 points right now. And S&P Futures higher by 16 as investors await the jobs report this morning.

We are also keeping an eye on a record spike in coronavirus cases here in the United States, plus the possibility of additional stimulus, the second half of the year. This after the third quarter kicked off yesterday with a mixed day for stocks, the NASDAQ close to another record high. Take a look at the NASDAQ, up another 95 points yesterday at 10,154. The Dow was down 77 but S&P higher by 15.

Global market this is morning are higher, growing hopes for a coronavirus vaccine pushing markets in Europe higher this morning. You've got Pfizer and BioNTech announcing promising data from its vaccine tests. And then encouraging vaccine news also drove markets in Asia overnight, and they were higher across the board, as you'll see, with the best performer Hang Seng and Hong Kong up about 3 percent overnight.

Well, the father of the teen shot and killed in Seattle's CHOP zone is now demanding answers from city officials. Cheryl Casone now with the details. Cheryl?

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NEWS ANCHOR: That's right, Maria. Good morning to you.

Horace Lorenzo Anderson Sr. is pleading for answers from the City of Seattle and police as he prepares to bury his son today.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

HORACE LORENZO ANDERSON SR., FATHER OF VICTIM: Somebody need to come to my house and knock on my door and tell me something, I don't know nothing. All I know that my son was -- he got killed out there and he's just this 19- year-old. That's Horace Lorenzo Anderson. That's my son, you know, and I love him. And that was my son.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Well, Horace Lorenzo Anderson Jr. was killed in the cop-free zone last month. Anderson Sr. says he found out about his son's death from his friends, not even the police. In fact, he still hasn't been contacted by any official from Seattle.

Seattle Police have begun the process of clearing out the zone following the mayor's emergency order. Police Chief Carmen Best slammed the city for allowing the zone to remain for far too long saying, quote, enough is enough.

As of last night, 44 arrests were made in the CHOP zone.

Well, don't forget to pack a face mask if you plan to fly on Delta Airlines. Carrier says passengers must wear a face mask before boarding and during the flight to help fight the spread of COVID-19. Anyone who does not comply risks being banned. Delta will give you a mask if you don't have one.

American, United and JetBlue are just some of the other major U.S. carriers that now require mask for passengers. Taking a look at shares, Delta, the premarket stock up almost 2 percent.

Finally, here's look at what is trending this morning on foxbusiness.com. California's gas tax rises 3.2 cents per gallon, bringing a total of 50.5 cents increase implemented as part of a 2017 law.

Chick-Fil-A is named the top restaurant in customer satisfaction for the sixth year in a row by the American Customer Satisfaction Index.

And Iowa becomes the first state to permanently legalize cocktails to-go. the temporary measure was initially enacted to provide businesses economic relief amid the coronavirus pandemic.

And those are your headlines, Maria, cheers from here, back over to you.

BARTIROMO: Yes, right back at you, Cheryl. Thank you.

Back to the boardwalk we go. Atlantic City casinos are rolling the dice this morning. They are reopening today. Casinos taking a major hit due to COVID-19, as you know.

And joining us right now is the chairman of the Hard Rock International and Seminole Gaming CEO, Jim Allen. Jim, it's good to see you, thank you so much for joining us. Good luck today.

What are your thoughts on Atlantic City's reopening and how are you protecting staff and customers?

JIM ALLEN, CHAIRMAN, HARD ROCK INTERNATIONAL: Good morning, Maria. Well, certainly, we are excited here in Atlantic City at the Hard Rock, bringing over 2,200 people back to work. It's been a rather challenging time. And, certainly, it's the peak of the Jersey Shore season coming into 4th of July weekend.

So, number one, we are excited about opening, and most importantly focusing on social distancing, focusing on the safety of our guests and employees.

BARTIROMO: So what are your expectations then? I mean, do you think that people will come out and start doing what they were doing a couple of months ago? How do you think -- how are you seeing things differently today?

ALLEN: You know, today is much different than it was, say, three, four days ago. Governor Murphy issued a new executive order, which eliminates indoor dining in the state of New Jersey and obviously here in the casinos. So we had to navigate through some last-minute plans.

One of the great things about the Hard Rock is we have over 4 million square feet in this particular complex. So we do have a lot of outdoor decks and dining areas so that we can obviously offer these amenities and still having some fun to our guests. But it certainly has been a challenge when we have 25 percent capacity.

Most importantly, it's about getting the employees back to work, you know, understanding this is going to be a slow ramp up but taking one step at a time, you know, making sure people are safe and sound.

BARTIROMO: Yes. So it's a slow ramp-up and, of course, the 25 percent capacity is something that will sort of limit the gains that you can have. But tell me how this pandemic has impacted your business. I mean, the loss of foot traffic over these last three months has -- had to have a hard hit. Will this have long-term effects?

ALLEN: You know, I certainly think the restaurant division, not just for Hard Rock Cafe but restaurants in general, really need to reevaluate what the long-term business plan is. We've actually spent over a hundred million dollars associated with cost regarding protection for employee's benefits, pay, et cetera, for coronavirus on a global basis.

Keep in mind, we are in 76 countries around the world, so we certainly have a lot more diversity than many companies.

We are pretty optimistic about the integrated resort, casino, hotel business on a long-term basis once the air lift and things like this starts coming somewhat back to normal. But, no doubt, restaurants, I think, are a category long-term that we're going to keep a very keen eye on focusing on what that business model is in the future.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And it looks like we are going to see real structural change to certain industries, restaurants maybe one of them.

You said 76 countries. Can you look out to all of the businesses across world and identify where you've seen growth even during this and what was the hardest hit in terms of this pandemic with all of your locations?

ALLEN: Yes, so at 100 percent. But interesting as each location opens, can we see actually different results? We saw results in Sacramento where, frankly, the business was up over 100 percent at first. It's kind of leveled off now to be at the 40, 50 percent area, which obviously is very strong. But if we look at the property, say, in South Florida, frankly, that ramp-up has been very slow and we are actually not even hitting last year's numbers.

As we look at our hotels even going to China, we are certainly starting to see some occupancies, you know, approaching the 60 percent area but certainly nowhere near more they were prior to COVID-19. So, globally, a city like London, we are not even open yet. So it really depends upon geographic location and very candidly the public's awareness as to how important they think corona or COVID is in their particular communities.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I think you make a really good point about China too, because I know for a long time, Macau was pretty much subsidizing everything else. The Chinese loved gambling and it was such an important business that it was subsidizing every other location. Then when you look at place like New Jersey, where you are now, they're not allowing indoor dining, no smoking, no drinking in the casinos, what does that do to the impact of this reopening this morning?

ALLEN: Well, you know, listen, I think one thing that's important is working with Governor Murphy, with the mayor, with the CRDA to still continue to focus on the larger plan as far as the revitalization of Atlantic City.

But when we think about Macau, we had a relationship with Laurence Ho in the City of Dreams, which, frankly, now we are back looking at that particular market, even in the most challenging times, Macau is still a very profitable gaming market, no doubt. When you look at the publicly- traded companies, the business in both Macau and, say, Singapore is obviously off where it was at its peak. But I think, long-term, there are still markets and, frankly, the companies that are in those particular markets will enjoy long-term profitability.

I think when you look at a market like Las Vegas --

BARTIROMO: Yes, go ahead.

ALLEN: -- a little different story.

BARTIROMO: Yes. In terms of Macau, I remember -- I went to Macau and it was just jam-packed and the business was talked about across the board within the industry that that was really where the growth was for the casino business in China, in Macau.

Any of this upset between the U.S. and China's relationship, do you think that's going to impact that growth that you're counting on in Macau?

ALLEN: You know, I definitely think it creates caution. I think as we look at the relationship between China and the United States, I think it's -- caution is the word. Certainly, the two countries have so much economic reliance on each other. But I think we have to respect that when we operate in these particular countries, we are a guest there and we need to comply with obviously the rules and regulations.

I think businesses that understand that can be proven to be very successful. And, frankly, our international operations and prior to COVID were doing extremely. Well so I think respect is the most important thing.

BARTIROMO: Yes, as always. Jim, it's good to have on the program this morning. Thank you so much. We wish the best for day one and the reopening this morning. Thank you. We will be watching.

Coming up, expanding access to telemedicine, how one company is reaching underserved communities amid pandemic. We're check out Teladoc.

And then protecting yourself against COVID-19. We will take a closer look at which masks are best with Dr. Mike later in the program. Don't miss that.

Plus, fiction becomes a reality. Sex and the City star Sarah Jessica Parker with a new show helping people find love.

You're watching MORNINGS WITH MARIA live on Fox Business.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Telehealth exploding due to coronavirus. A ground breaking new technology now is looking to make sure all Americans can access the virtual services from home. Qortex connecting health professionals with underserved communities using its first and only television-based telehealth program.

Joining us founder and CEO of Qortex and -- Founder of Qortex and CEO of MedSign, Tom Conroy. Tom, it's good to have you this morning, thanks so much for joining us.

I just love this idea. Congratulations. Walk us through how this technology works.

TOM CONROY, CEO, MEDSIGN: Well, it's real simple. It is the first of a kind technology that enables medical professionals to talk to their patients in the comfort of their home using what -- almost everybody knows how to use in the 120 million T.V. in mobile homes, is their television set.

And so I really created this for my 92-year-old World War II veteran. I didn't want my dad traveling in his car traveling to go to the hospital, to sit there and wait for his appointment rather in today's technology and especially in the world today, I wanted him to stay home, in the safety and comfort of his home.

BARTIROMO: I love that. And my 88-year-old parents are in the same spot but I feel like I can't really explain to them how to use an iPhone. So you're 92-year-old dad got it, understood how to work it on the T.V.?

CONROY: That's correct. It's a senior, simple design, and that was the emphasis when I first went through this. I said, you know, I've got to build something that's senior, simple, that they'll adopt and they'll embrace. And when you see the system and you use it, we have 90-year-olds using the system.

And there's a secondary role in this that's really important, not only can they talk to their medical professional, their doctor, but you can talk to your parents all through your T.V. set. Now, you're on T.V. all of the time, so they see, but for the rest of us, it's really neat. We call in to them, all they've got to do is press okay on the remote control and there I am on their television set, like a star --

BARTIROMO: I love it.

CONROY: -- talking and communicating (INAUDIBLE).

BARTIROMO: Really good idea. So you're running pilot programs with several leading hospitals right now. What's the feedback so far from the hospitals?

CONROY: Excellent. And the fact that it's -- they are reaching a demographic they can't reach right now. Just think about it, people over 65 for the most part are technology-averse, they live remote. This system, because I was telling you there's 120 million households with T.V.s, they have cable connections, they have internet.

And for those who can't -- I'm a satellite expert. I'm a retired military officer, worked in the space program. We can connect through satellite. So we are agnostic to the systems that provide the internet. We can connect to any hospital system and we can connect you through your iPhone to your mom and dad at home any time of the day.

BARTIROMO: I love it. Seniors need this so much. It's a good idea and this is where the job creation is.

Let me bring in Joanie Courtney, because, Joanie, you have been telling us for months and months is that that is where the jobs are in healthcare professionals. Tell us about this and what your reaction is to what Tom is telling us with this new technology, telehealth?

JOANIE COURTNEY, CHIEF WORKFORCE ANALYST, EMPLOYBRIDGE: Yes. Tom, it's very interesting to hear about this. We certainly see a strong demand for healthcare workers, you know, anything from physical therapists, registered nurses, physician assistants.

I'm actually curious, Tom, on how COVID has maybe accelerated your business or how you see it changing. Because we've certainly seen a tremendous amount of transformation, digital transformation accelerated with COVID. So how has COVID impacted your business?

CONROY: Well, telehealth is -- right now, it's like a tsunami. The growth in telehealth is going to be tremendous. I think it's around $10 billion, the estimate right now. And in five years, it's $200 billion.

But understand what I've done here with my team. We have a fabulous team at MedSign. What we have done is created a system to go after and reach a demographic that's not being touched right now. Seniors don't know how to use an iPhone or a tablet or a computer. We are talking 45 million seniors out there that have the potential, and not only in the United States, but let's talk about business section.

So when we have a worldwide global -- we can have a worldwide global impact by providing this service globally.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I just got my parents something called the GranPad for this very reason. It's not iPhone, it's just like a video chat.

But, Tom, you're right, you're hitting on a market that is right for change and in need. We'll be watching. It's good to see you this morning, tom. Thank you.

CONROY: Thank you very much, Maria, thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: Tom Conroy joining us there.

Coming up, fiction becomes a reality. Sex and the City star Sarah Jessica Parker out with a new show helping people find love. We will tell you about it.

You are watching MORNINGS WITH MARIA live on Fox Business.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Time for the morning buzz.

First up, how far would you go for love? Sarah Jessica Parker says pretty far. The actress is developing a new dating show for Lifetime called Swipe, Swap, where singles swap lives with a potential match in order to find love. That includes moving to each other's city, living in their homes, spending time with one another, with close friends and family.

Joanie Courtney, would you do it?

COURTNEY: Well, I don't think I'd do it but I think it's interesting. It's an interesting concept, certainly getting back into more reality T.V. of -- it's kind a combination, right, of Wife Swap and The Bachelor or dating shows. But I'm a big fan of Sarah Jessica Parker and Sex and the City, and I think she will get a lot of attention on this one.

BARTIROMO: But you're not exactly going to be moving in with somebody that you don't know. By the way, this is not Sarah Jessica Parker's first business venture. SJP joined me here on Fox Business back in 2014 when she launched her shoe line. She came into the studio and showed us all of the shoes that she was designing and they were beautiful. She has been actually an entrepreneur aside from her acting skills as well, and she showed it to us in New York.

Next up, a new study reveals Americans are facing more anxiety. 55 percent say that they were more stressed in May than in January before the pandemic. Of course, attributing the pressure to the lockdown and unemployment, no surprise here, Steve Moore?

STEVE MOORE, SENIOR ECONOMICS WRITER, THE WALL STREET JOURNAL: This is why we cannot continue to shut down this economy or return to a shutdown. There's a report today about very large increases in drug and alcohol abuse. You're seeing increases in depression, all sorts of social pathologies that have been related to this lockdown.

And it's so crazy because the thing that's best for your health, the one thing we do know now is sunlight and fresh air are the two best disinfectants. So get out this weekend, folks, don't be afraid and go out.

BARTIROMO: Yes, it's very good advice, Steve, because the sunshine does -- do something to your moods, it's true.

And finally, you don't have to travel to the Milky Way to feel like you're there. Check this out. NASA is preparing to launch and outer space-scented perfume. Scent was originally developed to train and prepare astronauts for what space smelled. Now, anybody can smell like a star, Brian. Would you wear it?

BRIAN: It smells like a seared stake, raspberries and rum, I will wear that any day, Maria. It sounds great.

BARTIROMO: Well, I don't know if that's what it smells like.

All right, a quick break, and then the Union Square Hospitality CEO will join us on the future of dining in New York City. Don't miss Danny Meyer coming up next hour on MORNINGS WITH MARIA live on Fox Business.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60X7-V8Y1-JCSC-J4R9-00000-00Focus: 'We're a tech company': Russia's Sberbank bets big on strategy shift2020-09-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:51:23ZLexisNexisNEWSFocus: 'We're a tech company': Russia's Sberbank bets big on strategy shiftAlexander Marrow

MOSCOW: Sberbank, Russia's dominant lender, is planning one of the biggest reinventions in its 179-year history as it seeks to join the likes of Apple and Google in the global pantheon of Big Tech. The company, which is dropping the word "bank" from its lo... MOSCOW: Sberbank, Russia's dominant lender, is planning one of the biggest reinventions...

MOSCOW: Sberbank, Russia's dominant lender, is planning one of the biggest reinventions in its 179-year history as it seeks to join the likes of Apple and Google in the global pantheon of Big Tech. The company, which is dropping the word "bank" from its lo...

MOSCOW: Sberbank, Russia's dominant lender, is planning one of the biggest reinventions in its 179-year history as it seeks to join the likes of Apple and Google in the global pantheon of Big Tech. The company, which is dropping the word "bank" from its logo as part of this drive, gave Reuters a preview of the devices it has developed to lead its charge – including a TV streaming box, virtual assistant and smart speaker – ahead of their official unveiling on Sept 24. Sberbank's Chief Technology Officer David Rafalovsky also said in an interview that it was launching "SmartMarket", an equivalent to Apple's AppStore or Google Play. "It's a huge investment, not a big investment. Even for a successful company, it's a huge investment," he said about the new range of gadgets and tech services, a potentially risky bet in an increasingly competitive market of domestic and foreign players. He declined to disclose the specific amount. The Russian government owns a stake of 50% plus one share in Sberbank, the country's oldest lender with assets of US$401bil (RM1.67 trillion) as of August and a market value of about US$67bil (RM279.26bil). In pursuit of a stronger presence in Russia's digital economy, it has invested in everything from cloud services to driverless cars in the past year. But the launch of in-house hardware marks a deeper move into tech; the company describes the new push as the "largest transformation" in its history. "We've always had a chip on our shoulder, we believe we are a technology company with a banking licence," Rafalovsky said, adding that most of its customers predominantly associate Sberbank with banking products. Sberbank announced the logo change and is unveiling the range of devices and services on Sept 24 at SberConf, a virtual event modelled on product launches by global technology firms. New gadgets: meet Salute Among Sberbank's new gadgets are SberBox, a TV streaming device, and SberPortal, a smart speaker with a screen attached which provides gesture and voice recognition. Sberbank is launching a family of virtual assistants, called Salute, which it said had more of a focus on emotional attachment than Apple's Siri, Hey Google or Amazon's Alexa. It is built into all Sberbank's devices and mobile apps. What sets it apart from other voice assistants on the market is that it has three personalities, Rafalovsky said. They are "cultured Sber, cheerful Joy and pedantic Athena," Sberbank said. The company's SmartMarket, meanwhile, will have coding tools available for businesses and entrepreneurs to produce their own apps and a revenue-share model where Sberbank will only take money from apps that charge money. "It's strategically important because SmartMarket instruments act as a bridge for the entire market into our ecosystem," said Rafalovsky. Tech's a risky business The new products will initially be targeted at the Russian market, where Sberbank says it serves almost 100 million active banking clients, though it operates in 17 other countries and the devices could potentially be rolled out abroad at a later date. Western technology companies have traditionally seen Russia as an attractive but high-risk market, due to the threat of sanctions and Russian laws such as those passed in 2015 requiring all data about Russian citizens to be stored in the country. Amazon does not have a big presence in Russia, whose sheer geographical size makes logistics daunting, Microsoft's LinkedIn is blocked after a court found it breached the data storage rule, while domestic players dominate web searches and social networks. However, Sberbank's costly tech push could be both risky and challenging, with no guarantees of success in a fragmented and increasingly competitive hardware and software market. Apple, Samsung and Huawei are leading players in smart devices, with a wealth of experience, developed app ecosystems and deep pockets. Local player Ivi and others already offer TV streaming services, while Mail.ru, Internet group Yandex and mobile operator MTS all have smart speakers on the market. In June, Sberbank and Yandex – known as Russia's answer to Google – said they would stop working together on joint projects, including e-commerce venture Yandex.Market and payment service Yandex.Money, with non-compete agreements expiring in the third quarter, potentially putting the two in direct competition. Life beyond banking While Sberbank's diversification drive could carry risks, analysts say it has become increasingly difficult for banks to make money in Russia, where the key interest rate is languishing at a historic low of 4.25%, while rates are negative in some of their European markets. BCS Global Markets analyst Elena Tsareva said banking was becoming lower margin and more regulated, and that it was being disrupted by new, nimble players such as online lender Tinkoff, which Yandex is in talks to acquire. Against that backdrop, it makes sense for Sberbank to move into new areas, Tsareva said. "How do you earn money if you do banking business only?" she added. – Reuters

Apple AAPL.O , Samsung 005930.KS and Huawei are leading players in smart devices, with a wealth of experience, developed app ecosystems and deep pockets. Local player Ivi and others already offer TV streaming services, while Mail.ru MAILRq.L , internet group Yandex YNDX.O and mobile operator MTS MTSS.MM all have smart speakers on the market. BCS Global Markets analyst Elena Tsareva said banking was becoming lower margin and more regulated, and that it was being disrupted by new, nimble players such as online lender Tinkoff, which Yandex is in talks to acquire. Against that backdrop, it makes sense for Sberbank to move into new areas, Tsareva said. “How do you earn money if you do banking business only?” she added.

urn:contentItem:60X7-V9Y1-JCSC-J30N-00000-00FOCUS-'We're a tech company': Russia's Sberbank bets big on strategy shift2020-09-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:51:22ZLexisNexisNEWSFOCUS-'We're a tech company': Russia's Sberbank bets big on strategy shiftAlexander Marrow

MOSCOW (Reuters) - Sberbank SBER.MM , Russia's dominant lender, is planning one of the biggest reinventions in its 179-year history as it seeks to join the likes of Apple and Google in the global pantheon of Big Tech. The company, which is dropping the wor... MOSCOW (Reuters) - Sberbank SBER.MM , Russia's dominant lender, is planning one...

MOSCOW (Reuters) - Sberbank SBER.MM , Russia's dominant lender, is planning one of the biggest reinventions in its 179-year history as it seeks to join the likes of Apple and Google in the global pantheon of Big Tech. The company, which is dropping the wor...

MOSCOW (Reuters) - Sberbank SBER.MM , Russia's dominant lender, is planning one of the biggest reinventions in its 179-year history as it seeks to join the likes of Apple and Google in the global pantheon of Big Tech. The company, which is dropping the word “bank” from its logo as part of this drive, gave Reuters a preview of the devices it has developed to lead its charge - including a TV streaming box, virtual assistant and smart speaker - ahead of their official unveiling on Thursday. Sberbank’s Chief Technology Officer David Rafalovsky also said in an interview that it was launching “SmartMarket”, an equivalent to Apple’s AppStore or Google Play. “It’s a huge investment, not a big investment. Even for a successful company, it’s a huge investment,” he said about the new range of gadgets and tech services, a potentially risky bet in an increasingly competitive market of domestic and foreign players. He declined to disclose the specific amount. The Russian government owns a stake of 50% plus one share in Sberbank, the country’s oldest lender with assets of $401 billion as of August and a market value of about $67 billion. In pursuit of a stronger presence in Russia’s digital economy, it has invested in everything from cloud services to driverless cars in the past year. But the launch of in-house hardware marks a deeper move into tech; the company describes the new push as the “largest transformation” in its history. “We’ve always had a chip on our shoulder, we believe we are a technology company with a banking licence,” Rafalovsky said, adding that most of its customers predominantly associate Sberbank with banking products. Sberbank announced the logo change and is unveiling the range of devices and services on Thursday at SberConf, a virtual event modelled on product launches by global technology firms. NEW GADGETS: MEET SALUTE Among Sberbank’s new gadgets are SberBox, a TV streaming device, and SberPortal, a smart speaker with a screen attached which provides gesture and voice recognition. Sberbank is launching a family of virtual assistants, called Salute, which it said had more of a focus on emotional attachment than Apple’s Siri, Hey Google or Amazon’s Alexa. It is built into all Sberbank’s devices and mobile apps. What sets it apart from other voice assistants on the market is that it has three personalities, Rafalovsky said. They are “cultured Sber, cheerful Joy and pedantic Athena,” Sberbank said. The company’s SmartMarket, meanwhile, will have coding tools available for businesses and entrepreneurs to produce their own apps and a revenue-share model where Sberbank will only take money from apps that charge money. “It’s strategically important because SmartMarket instruments act as a bridge for the entire market into our ecosystem,” said Rafalovsky. TECH’S A RISKY BUSINESS The new products will initially be targeted at the Russian market, where Sberbank says it serves almost 100 million active banking clients, though it operates in 17 other countries and the devices could potentially be rolled out abroad at a later date. Western technology companies have traditionally seen Russia as an attractive but high-risk market, due to the threat of sanctions and Russian laws such as those passed in 2015 requiring all data about Russian citizens to be stored in the country. Amazon does not have a big presence in Russia, whose sheer geographical size makes logistics daunting, Microsoft’s LinkedIn is blocked after a court found it breached the data storage rule, while domestic players dominate web searches and social networks. However Sberbank’s costly tech push could be both risky and challenging, with no guarantees of success in a fragmented and increasingly competitive hardware and software market. Apple AAPL.O , Samsung 005930.KS and Huawei are leading players in smart devices, with a wealth of experience, developed app ecosystems and deep pockets. Local player Ivi and others already offer TV streaming services, while Mail.ru MAILRq.L , internet group Yandex YNDX.O and mobile operator MTS MTSS.MM all have smart speakers on the market. In June, Sberbank and Yandex - known as Russia’s answer to Google - said they would stop working together on joint projects, including e-commerce venture Yandex.Market and payment service Yandex.Money, with non-compete agreements expiring in the third quarter, potentially putting the two in direct competition. LIFE BEYOND BANKING While Sberbank’s diversification drive could carry risks, analysts say it has become increasingly difficult for banks to make money in Russia, where the key interest rate is languishing at a historic low of 4.25%, while rates are negative in some of their European markets. BCS Global Markets analyst Elena Tsareva said banking was becoming lower margin and more regulated, and that it was being disrupted by new, nimble players such as online lender Tinkoff, which Yandex is in talks to acquire. Against that backdrop, it makes sense for Sberbank to move into new areas, Tsareva said. “How do you earn money if you do banking business only?” she added.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VPG-WJN1-DY91-K511-00000-00Following Google's EU fine, regulators shift their sights;Heat may now be on other big tech giants, such as Amazon, Apple and Facebook2019-03-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:51:22ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. B3Following Google's EU fine, regulators shift their sightsHeat may now be on other big tech giants, such as Amazon, Apple and FacebookAoife White BloombergBRUSSELS

U.S. tech giants might have a respite after two decades of European Union antitrust investigations. But not for long.

While Google just got a third, and possibly final, EU fine on Wednesday, regulators still have their eyes on Amazon.com Inc., Apple Inc. and Facebook Inc.

EU antitrust chief, Margrethe Vestager, told reporters earlier this month that an early-stage probe into Amazon's potential use of data to overtake smaller shops on its Marketplace platform is "quite advanced" and she'd "like to take more decisive steps" before she leaves office later this year. That might see the start of a full-blown investigation.

She's also promised to examine a complaint Spotify Technology SA made targeting Apple's app store and has said she "takes an interest" in potential anti-competitive behaviour by Facebook.

The 1.49 billion-euro ($2.2-billion) fine levied Wednesday against Alphabet Inc.'s Google for thwarting advertising rivals was the third time Vestager penalized the U.S. tech giant.

There are new cops doing the rounds too - privacy authorities in countries armed with the power to levy fines of as much as 4 per cent of a company's annual sales for breaching the EU's new data rules.

'The truth is that many regard Google and Facebook as out of control," Jonathan Compton, a partner at DMH Stallard in the U.K., said in an email after Wednesday's fine. "The deeper problem is what to do about it. Even if you make the decision to regulate the big platforms, and that is an issue in itself involving freedom of expression, how can those platforms regulate their content when they have two billion or so users?"

Ireland's data protection commissioner Helen Dixon is already looking into at least seven privacy probes targeting Facebook, with several other investigations her office opened targeting "very big internet companies," she said in an interview in February.

France's data watchdog in January levied a record 50 million-euro fine against Google, which showed that watchdogs are taking the new guidelines seriously.

Amazon is also facing a probe by Germany's Federal Cartel Office, which last month made worldwide headlines by striking at Facebook's user-data policy.

Internet platforms usually raise concerns because of their "double role" as marketplace providers that also compete with companies offering services on the portals, Andreas Mundt, head of the regulator, told reporters in Berlin on Thursday. The German Amazon probe is likely to become another "sample case" just like the Facebook order is, he said.

New regulatory risks for tech companies are emerging. The EU agreed to new rules for online platforms in February that require internet firms to address some issues that have triggered antitrust cases. They will have to provide clear terms of service, more transparency about how products are ranked, and to establish a system for handling complaints. Companies are also required under the new rules to "exhaustively disclose" any advantage they give their own products.

A copyright reform finalized last month forces web firms to compensate publishers and creators for the content that appears on their websites.

At the same time EU regulators are demanding Twitter Inc., Facebook and Google do more to fight disinformation on the internet ahead of May elections.

urn:contentItem:5XGP-3C61-F03R-N3K3-00000-00Follow Morgan Stanley to Trade 2020 Election With ETFs2019-11-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:51:22ZLexisNexisFollow Morgan Stanley to Trade 2020 Election With ETFsSweta Killa

Nov 12, 2019( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex) America's poll is a year away and the race to presidency may bring a lot of volatility and uncertainty to the stock market, which is currently hovering at an all-time high. According to the Stock Trader's Almanac, the Dow Jones Industrial Average has climbed 10.1%[1] on average during election years since 1952 when a sitting president has run for reelection. Over the same period, the blue-chip average has fallen 1.6% during election years when there's an open field.Per John LaForge, head of retail asset strategy for Wells Fargo Investment Institute, the Dow Jones has had an average return of 7.6% during presidential election years since 1900, and positive returns 70% of the time during those 30 occurrences. Bonds and stocks historically struggled in the first half of election years and rose later in the year (read: 9 High-Flying ETFs of 2019[2]).The two key Democratic presidential candidates are Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders, who will battle it out with Donald Trump.

Wall Street experts forecast major losses for the U.S. stock market if Democrat Elizabeth Warren wins the 2020 presidential election.As such, Morgan Stanley outlined four outcomes of the 2020 election and its strategies[3] for investors on how to make the most of them.Democrats Win White House, Split CongressUnder this scenario, alternative energy stocks would gain, and oil and gas stocks along with big banks will lose. This is because Elizabeth Warren has hyped an ambitious climate change plan, calling for $3 trillion in spending to move the United States to 100% clean energy under a 10-year plan and safeguard poorer communities that are dependent on the production of fossil fuels.As such, investors could invest in alternative energy ETFs like iShares Global Clean Energy ETF ICLN[4], Invesco Cleantech ETF PZD[5], Invesco WilderHill Clean Energy ETF PBW[6] and First Trust NASDAQ Clean Edge Green Energy Index Fund QCLN[7] (read: Clean Energy ETFs Riding Higher[8]).Republicans Win White House, Split CongressIn this scenario, where if President Trump is reelected and Congress remains divided between a Republican Senate and a Democratic House, bank and oil stocks will be the biggest winners. The status quo will fuel the gradual rollback of banking, and oil and gas regulations.Given this, bank funds — SPDR S...ank ETF KBE[9], Invesco KBW Bank ETF KBWB[10], SPDR S...egional Banking ETF KRE[11] and iShares U.S. Regional Banks ETF IAT[12] — and oil ETFs like SPDR S...il ...s Exploration ...oduction ETF XOP[13], Energy Select Sector SPDR Fund XLE[14], and VanEck Vectors Oil Services ETF OIH[15] could see continued upside (read: Trump May See Easy "Win in 2020:" ETFs to Bet On[16]).Democrats Sweep White House, CongressIn this outcome, where if Democrats take the White House as well as both chambers of Congress, the unified government will likely expand spending on health care, transportation and infrastructure, thereby providing a boost to these sectors. As a result, investors could invest in some of the popular healthcare ETFs like Health Care Select Sector SPDR FundXLV[17], Vanguard Healthcare ETF VHT[18], iShares Nasdaq Biotechnology ETF IBB[19] and SPDR S...iotech ETF XBI[20] (read: Healthcare ETFs Win in October: Here's Why[21]).Transportation funds iShares Transportation Average ETF IYT[22], SPDR S...ransportation ETF XTN[23] and First Trust Nasdaq Transportation ETF FTXR[24] will also see smooth trading under this scenario. However, the Democratic coalition would call for heightened scrutiny and pressure on big financial firms, big tech and big pharma.Republicans Sweep White House, CongressThe last outcome could be Republicans taking back the House and Trump staying back in the White House. This could propel the current pace of deregulation. U.S. oil and gas, financial firms and telecommunication companies would see a boon while emerging markets could come under pressure if the U.S. dollar strengthens further.Here again, bank and oil ETFs will see solid trading while emerging market ETFs like Vanguard FTSE Emerging Markets ETF VWO[25], iShares Core MSCI Emerging Markets ETF IEMG[26] and iShares MSCI Emerging Markets ETF EEM[27] willcontinued to struggle (read: Emerging Market ETFs Beating the Broader Market: Here's How[28]).Want key ETF info delivered straight to your inbox?Zacks' free Fund Newsletter will brief you on top news and analysis, as well as top-performing ETFs, each week. Get it free >>[29] Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? Today, you can download 7 Best Stocks for the Next 30 Days. Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VP8-F5D1-DXXY-3130-00000-00For advertising tack, E.U. fines Google $1.7 billion more2019-03-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:51:22ZLexisNexisA-SECTIONPg. A13Every ZoneFor advertising tack, E.U. fines Google $1.7 billion moreTony Romm

European regulators fined Google about $1.7 billion Wednesday on charges that its advertising practices violated antitrust laws, the third time in as many years that the region's watchdogs have penalized the U.S. tech giant for harming competition and consumers.

Europe's actions stand in stark contrast to the United States, where regulators - facing a flood of complaints that big tech companies have become too large and powerful - have not brought an antitrust case against Google or any of its peers in recent years, reflecting a widening transatlantic schism over Silicon Valley and its business practices.

Margrethe Vestager, the European Union's top competition commissioner, said Google had engaged in "illegal practices" in a bid to "cement its dominant market position" in the search and advertising markets. She also said additional antitrust scrutiny of the tech giant was still to come.

The new penalty adds to Google's costly headaches in Europe, where Vestager has fined the tech giant more than $9 billion, citing antitrust violations.

Reacting to Wednesday's fine, Kent Walker, Google's senior vice president of global affairs, stressed in a statement that the company already has made "a wide range of changes to our products to address the [European] Commission's concerns." Google did not say whether it would appeal the E.U. decision.

In 2018, Vestager took aim at the company's Android smartphone operating system, saying that Google pressured mobile device-makers to pre-install the tech giant's apps.

A year before that, Vestager punished Google for giving its shopping-comparison service a better placement in search results over rivals' offerings. In both cases, Google has started tweaking its business practices in Europe to comply with the law while appealing E.U. decisions in court.

The company's changes include a new effort, detailed Tuesday, to help owners of Android smartphones find and use competing search and Web-browsing services. The update applies only to Europe, Google said in a blog post, without indicating whether it would alter any of its mobile practices in the United States. It still earned some early praise from Vestager, who said Wednesday that the company has the "potential to give users a real choice."

Vestager's latest punishment targets Google's relationships with third-party websites, from large retailers to small gossip blogs. Sites that participated in Google's "AdSense for Search" program could take advantage of Google's search tools on their Web pages, and users who searched those sites would see results alongside ads served up by Google.

But Google for a time prohibited those third-party sites from using rival ad services, then required prominent placement of its own ads - two of the many restrictions on AdSense customers that led the European Commission, the administrative arm of the European Union, to conclude in an initial complaint filed in 2016 that Google had acted in an anti-competitive way.

E.U. officials acknowledged in 2016 that Google had changed its AdSense contracts to allow for "more freedom to display competing search ads."

But the decision announced Wednesday prohibits the company from introducing any such ad restrictions in the future while opening the door for Google to face lawsuits from "any person or business affected by its anti-competitive" tactics, the European Union said.

"There was no reason for Google to include these restrictive clauses in their contracts except to keep rivals out of the market," Vestager said.

The Google fine is the European Union's latest broadside against the tech industry. Vestager previously has acknowledged an ongoing antitrust investigation against Amazon, and earlier this month, she said the inquiry is in a "quite advanced" stage. (Amazon founder and chief executive Jeffrey P. Bezos owns The Washington Post.)

Music-streaming site Spotify, meanwhile, has urged European regulators to take similar aim at Apple, alleging last week that the iPhone giant has an "unfair advantage" because of the subscription-related fees it charges certain app makers. Individual European countries - emboldened with tough online privacy laws that took effect last year - also have set their sights on Silicon Valley. A key regulatory agency in Ireland recently confirmed it has opened 10 investigations into Facebook and its data-collection practices.

Google could face additional penalties in the European Union, where Vestager - who has emerged as one of Silicon Valley's toughest regulators - is set to finish her term as competition commissioner at the end of October. Regulators recently have started scrutinizing Google's handling of local search results, following a complaint brought by Yelp last year.

"We're still looking into the search market for jobs and the search market for locals," Vestager said Wednesday. "We keep getting complaints from people who are concerned about how these markets work."

tony.romm@washpost.com

But the decision announced Wednesday prohibits the company from introducing any such ad restrictions in the future while opening the door for Google to face lawsuits from "any person or business affected by its anti-competitive" tactics, the European Union said.

"There was no reason for Google to include these restrictive clauses in their contracts except to keep rivals out of the market," Vestager said.

The Google fine is the European Union's latest broadside against the tech industry. Vestager previously has acknowledged an ongoing antitrust investigation against Amazon, and earlier this month, she said the inquiry is in a "quite advanced" stage. (Amazon founder and chief executive Jeffrey P. Bezos owns The Washington Post.)

Music-streaming site Spotify, meanwhile, has urged European regulators to take similar aim at Apple, alleging last week that the iPhone giant has an "unfair advantage" because of the subscription-related fees it charges certain app makers. Individual European countries - emboldened with tough online privacy laws that took effect last year - also have set their sights on Silicon Valley. A key regulatory agency in Ireland recently confirmed it has opened 10 investigations into Facebook and its data-collection practices.

Google could face additional penalties in the European Union, where Vestager - who has emerged as one of Silicon Valley's toughest regulators - is set to finish her term as competition commissioner at the end of October. Regulators recently have started scrutinizing Google's handling of local search results, following a complaint brought by Yelp last year.

"We're still looking into the search market for jobs and the search market for locals," Vestager said Wednesday. "We keep getting complaints from people who are concerned about how these markets work."

tony.romm@washpost.com

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5GBB-RYT1-DYR7-R36W-00000-00For a glimpse of driverless future, ask a farmer2015-06-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:51:22ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. D3For a glimpse of driverless future, ask a farmer

By Andrea Peterson

The Washington Post

Google has received tons of gushy press for its bubble-shaped self-driving car, although it's still years from the showroom floor. But for years, John Deere has been selling tractors that practically drive themselves for use on farms in America's heartland, where there are few pesky pedestrians or federal rules to get in the way.

For a glimpse at the future, meet Jason Poole, a 34-year-old crop consultant from Kansas. After a long day of meetings this month and driving five hours across the state to watch his little girl's softball game, he was still able to run his John Deere tractor until 2 a.m., thanks to technology that left most of the driving to a computer.

The land is hilly on Poole's family farm, so he drives the first curved row manually and handles the turns himself to teach the layout to his tractor's guidance system. But after that, he takes his hands off the steering wheel and allows the tractor to finish.

"We kind of laugh when we see news stories about self-driving cars, because we've had that for years," Poole said.

The advancements being rolled out on the farm could soon show up next door: Your neighbor can already replace his lawn mower with the John Deere equivalent of a Roomba robotic vacuum for his yard.

The self-driving technology being sold by John Deere and some of its competitors is less technically complex than the fully driverless cars that big tech companies and car manufacturers are working on. For now, the tractors are still supposed to have a driver behind the wheel - even if they never touch it.

They've already started to transform farming in America and abroad: John Deere is selling auto-steering and other self-guidance tech in more than 100 countries, said Cory Reed, vice president of the company's Intelligent Solutions Group.

"John Deere is the largest operator of autonomous vehicles," said Catherine Sandoval, a California public utilities commissioner, at a recent event hosted by the Federal Trade Commission.

Some farmers aren't shy about their enthusiasm for the technology - even uploading videos showing it off online. One appears to show a tractor hauling a planter making a tightly choreographed turn without a driver in the cab. In another, the driver takes pictures, throws paper airplanes and balances a water bottle on his nose before appearing to nod off while the tractor keeps working his field.

The systems come with their own risks, including concerns that they could be hacked. But because farm-equipment makers operate almost exclusively on private land, they've been able to bring products to market much more quickly than consumer automakers - and without the same level of regulatory scrutiny.

There are no federal rules specifically addressing self-driving tech for tractors, largely because farm equipment is designed for use in fields where it doesn't pose the same level of risk to other vehicles or people as a self-driving vehicle on a public road. The closest thing to national regulations are safety standards set by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, but the agency does not have any rules directly aimed at self-driving technology.

That lack of regulations is one reason that the future reached the farm first. But another is pure necessity: There's a labor crunch in rural America.

John Deere isn't the only company selling this kind of technology; its main competitor, Case IH, markets similar systems, as do lesser-known companies. Some are going even further than modifying existing tractor designs: The aptly named Autonomous Tractor Corp. designed a fully autonomous tractor prototype that looks like a golden, boxy tank, but without a seat for a driver.

The systems are pricey: Outfitting a new tractor with top-of-the-line auto-steering, navigation and guidance tech could cost upward of $20,000, Reed said. There are also activation and subscription fees if farmers want to use the company's satellite or radio signals.

Jeff Barger | Visual Services-East Moline | John Deere This John Deere harvester and grain cart in Illinois has an operator at the wheel, as required, but it's being driven by satellite guidance to improve precision.
